Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Mines & Resources,
Ottawa.

Re: St. Clair School.

Miss F. Elford, teacher, has requested that some interior alterations and repairs be performed at the St. Clair Indian Day School on Sarnia Reserve during summer holidays. At present there are several poorly constructed, old and more or less useless cupboards and boxes in various places in the classroom. Some of these are movable but others have been fastened to the walls in inconvenient places. These boxes, shelves, etc., are directly below and in front of side blackboards which prevent pupils from making use of the blackboard space. The teacher wishes to have these removed and replaced with one compact cupboard and one wall case complete with shelving. If this were done it would improve the general appearance of the class room, make more floor space available and be more satisfactory in every way.

The teacher states that quite a number of new pupils will be starting to school next September. For these beginners she wishes us to provide a large kindergarten work table. The younger pupils would receive their instruction at this table which should have drawers to hold their individual books, seatwork, pencils, crayons, plasticine and other primary materials. Miss Elford expects that there will be about 55 pupils next Fall and considers that such a large number of pupils cannot be handled properly unless a kindergarten table is supplied complete with drawers and benches to accommodate about twelve primary pupils.

Miss Elford also asks that small platforms about 10" high and 30" wide be built in front of all blackboards so that younger pupils may be able to reach all blackboards without stretching

(Over)
or standing on tip-toe. At present all immovable blackboards are quite high on the wall and only the older and taller children can use them. This teacher also wishes us to do something regarding the blackboard across the front of the class room. Portions of its surface are rough and worn and the teacher thinks that an entirely new board is necessary. The front blackboard has an area of 79 1/3 square feet. Rather than buy a new board I suggest that some blackboard paint for resurfacing could be purchased which would perhaps renew the board satisfactorily.

The materials for all of the above mentioned repairs and alterations would cost approximately $40.00. All labour could be performed by a capable Indian carpenter, James B. Williams, at an estimated cost of $25.00. This would make a total estimated expenditure of $65.00. Materials could be purchased locally and accounts for them as well as labour could be submitted under cover of vouchers to the Department for payment.

I recommend that this work be done as I believe it is necessary in the best interests of the teacher and pupils at St. Clair Indian Day School.

Kindly advise if expenditures as detailed above will be approved by the Department.

M. W. McCracken,

Ottawa, July 4, 1944.

Mr. M.W. McCracken, Indian Agent, Sarnia, Ontario,

With reference to yours of the 29th ultimo, the Department approves an expenditure of $65.00 for material and labour in making interior alterations and repairs to the St. Clair Indian Day School.

We are ordering from the Government Stationery Office the blackboard paint which you state is needed.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.
Sarnia, July 8th, 1944

Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Mines & Resources, Ottawa.

Some of the Indians of the Sarnia Band have considered that warning signs should be placed at a dangerous intersection of roads on their Reserve. The St. Clair Indian Day School is situated on a corner of the intersection where there is considerable traffic in both directions. As a protection to the children it has been suggested that two "Stop Signs" be placed on one road, two "Slow Down Signs" on the other road, and four "School-Go Slow Signs". Kindly advise if these are procurable from the Indian Affairs Branch. If so, I would appreciate if they could be forwarded to this office. Signs appearing on the King's Highway throughout the Province of Ontario would be suitable.

M. W. McCracken,

REPORT ON SARNIA INDIAN AGENCY FOR THE MONTH OF AUGUST, 1944.

Repair work, alterations to cupboards, and the building of a kindergarten table and benches was completed at the St. Clair Indian Day School on Sarnia Reserve at a cost of $75.00. This work was necessary and is a great improvement.

M.W. McCracken,
Indian Agent.
Sarnia, October 11, 1944.

Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Mines & Resources,
OTTAWA.

The question of supplying hot lunches to pupils attending Day School in the Sarnia Agency has been discussed with the teachers. Miss Elford, teacher of the St. Clair School considers that the Department should supply 8 quarts of fresh milk each day for the period December 1, 1944 to March 31, 1945. This is an increased amount over previous years as there is now a larger attendance at the St. Clair School. The teacher does not think it necessary for the Department to buy canned soup, cocoa or sugar as much of this could be brought by the children themselves. I recommend that the Department approve of supplying milk to this school during the winter months.

The two teachers at Kettle Point consider that fresh milk as well as canned soup, cocoa and sugar should be supplied by the Department. I am in favour of purchasing the milk but see little necessity for any additional expenditures for soup or cocoa. I think the children could bring potatoes, beans, peas, corn and cocoa which would enable them to make their own soup and hot drinks. In practically every case the parents are working and it would be no hardship on them to furnish the above at their own expense. I am in favour of supplying four quarts of milk to the senior room and four quarts to the junior room at Kettle Point School. If the Department thinks that soup should also be purchased for these schools I shall be glad to list the quantities needed.

M. W. McCracken

MWM: FM

M. W. McCracken,
INDIAN AGENT.
Ottawa,
October 13, 1944.

EX'D.

Mr. M.W. McCracken, Indian Agent, Sarnia, Ont.

Re: Provision for noonday lunches - St. Clair and Kettle Point Day Schools.

I have for acknowledgment your letter of the 11th instant, in which you seek Departmental authority to provide noonday lunches, particularly milk, at the above-noted schools.

It will be satisfactory to the Department if, in co-operation with the teachers, you make arrangements for the supply of milk necessary for the pupils at these schools. It seems to the officials here highly desirable that the lunches provided at our schools should be measurably uniform. We are disposed, therefore, to agree with you when you state that in your judgment soup and cocoa should not be provided at Kettle Point.

R.A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Sarnia, January 2nd, 1945.

Indian Affairs Branch, Dept. Mines & Resources,
OTTAWA.

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter 29-1-5 of December 29, 1944, with reference to chalk which was purchased for use at the St. Clair Indian Day School on Sarnia Reserve.

Miss Elford, the teacher, had already purchased two boxes of chalk which she paid for herself. The receipted account for these two boxes was dated December 16th although the purchase was actually made several weeks previous to that date.

When we were informed that chalk could not be supplied from the Department I authorized Miss Elford to buy four additional boxes as per account under cover of voucher 284.

There has not been a duplication and I recommend payment of vouchers 280 and 284 which cover six boxes of chalk.

M. W. McCracken

M. W. McCracken,
INDIAN AGENT.
Ottawa, December 29, 1941.

Mr. M. W. McCracken, Indian Agent, Sarnia, Ont.

I am in receipt of your voucher No. 284, for $4.00, covering the cost of four boxes of chalk supplied to the St. Clair Indian Day School. The first of this week we received a voucher from you, covering the cost of two boxes of chalk. Both the account attached to your previous voucher and the account attached to your voucher No. 284 are dated December 16. Is there any duplication or is the Department to understand that six boxes of chalk have been purchased?

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

Sarnia, Ontario,
May 4, 1945.

Indian Affairs Branch, Dept. of Mines & Resources,
OTTAWA.

A resolution was passed by the Sarnia Band at their regular monthly meeting held on May 1st to the effect that accommodation at the St. Clair Indian Day School is inadequate and that the Department be requested to take immediate steps to relieve the situation by providing an additional class room and teacher for the Sarnia Reserve.

Addition class room space is urgently required and the action requested by the Council is recommended.

In any event, your early reply indicating whether or not any action in this regard is proposed for this year, would be appreciated.

C. Roberts,
Acting Indian Agent.

CR:T

MAY 9 1945
Ottawa, May 11, 1945.

Mr. C. Roberts, Acting Indian Agent,
Sarnia, Ont.

I have your letter of the 4th instant, with reference to the necessity for providing additional accommodation at the St. Clair Indian Day School.

I discussed your letter with the Acting Director yesterday, and I regret that it was not possible to include, in our current year's appropriation, an amount that would be required to provide additional classroom space. We are including an item in the post-war program for the erection of an extra building at this school.

If the St. Clair School will not accommodate the number of children who wish to attend for the academic year 1945-46, the Department is agreeable to having you make arrangements with the Sarnia Public School to accept those pupils who cannot be accommodated at our own school. If this action is necessary, I suggest that those living closest to Sarnia should be enrolled in the Sarnia Public School. However, it should be distinctly understood with the Sarnia School Board that the Department will not be responsible for payment of tuition grants for these children unless the Board has received a letter from you authorizing the admission.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

Dear Sir:

Your letter of May 21st, inquiring if arrangements can be made to admit sixteen additional pupils from the Sarnia Reserve to the Sarnia Public Schools next school year, was presented to the members of the Board of Education at the regular meeting held Monday evening last and the following resolution was adopted:

"That the Department of Indian Affairs be informed that, due to overcrowding in the City schools, there is no room for children coming in from the Reserve."

This means that all pupils from outside the city limits who are already in attendance and paying fees will not be permitted to return to Sarnia schools in the fall and the parents of these pupils are being so advised.

Yours very truly,

(Mrs.) M. B. Beasley
Secretary-Treasurer.
Secy-Treas. & School Supt.,
Board of Education,
275 Wellington Street,
Sarnia, Ontario.

Dear Sir:

Owing to crowded conditions in the St. Clair Indian Day School on the Sarnia Reserve, Departmental authority has been obtained for the admission of a number of pupils in Sarnia Public Schools if such can be arranged. Present estimates indicate accommodation will be required for approximately sixteen additional Indian pupils, as follows:

| Grade | Number |
|-------|--------|
| IV    | 6      |
| V     | 4      |
| VI    | 5      |
| VII   | 1      |

The Indian Affairs Branch of the Department of Mines & Resources will be responsible for tuition fees of pupils so enrolled - although it should be clearly understood that the Department will not be responsible for payment of tuition grants for others than those for whom the Board has received a letter of authorization from this office.

Would you kindly advise me at your convenience as to the likelihood of accommodation for the pupils referred to, being available.

I should be pleased to discuss the foregoing with you personally - or with the Board - at any time.

Yours very truly,

C. Roberts,
Acting Indian Agent.
Sarnia, Ont., June 7, 1945.

Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Mines & Resources,
Ottawa.

On receipt of Departmental letter dated May 11th, file 29-1-5, a letter was written to the Sarnia Board of Education - copy of which is attached - enquiring into the possibility of accommodating additional Indian pupils.

A reply has been received today - copy of which is also attached - and which is self-explanatory.

There will be approximately 70 pupils of school age on the Sarnia reserve next September - and, the present class room having a seating capacity of 40, there will be a surplus of 30 pupils. (There are 52 pupils now on the roll but the present teacher informs me she could not possibly carry on under present conditions for another year).

The foregoing facts are submitted for your consideration.

It is obvious additional class room space is essential before the beginning of the new term.

C. Roberts,
Acting Indian Agent.

Ottawa, June 12, 1945.

Mr. C. Roberts,
Acting Indian Agent, Sarnia, Ont.

I have your letter of the 7th instant, with reference to the situation at the St. Clair School. It is noted that the Sarnia Public School Board will not be able to accommodate any of the Indian children.

I have just discussed your letter very fully with the Acting Director, and frankly we do not know what we can do in the matter. No funds were specifically provided in the current year's appropriation for the erection of an addition to the St. Clair School. We have included this new addition in the first year of our post-war program, but exactly when that will commence, it is impossible for me to say. The only other possible solution is that, if there is a building on the St. Clair Reserve, it could be rented for school purposes, temporarily, for a year or so. It is quite possible that you have already considered this suggestion.

I have your letter of the 18th instant, advising the Department that it may be possible to secure the new council hall for the coming academic year, to serve as a second classroom for the St. Clair School.

In reply to Departmental letter dated June 12th, file 29-1-5, I have to advise the only building which might be rented as a classroom on the Sarnia Reserve will be the new Council Hall when completed. I have discussed this with the Chief and Council and they appear to be agreeable to such arrangements. However, this will be discussed further, and the necessary Band Resolution passed at the next regular Council meeting. At that time the question of an appropriate rental will also be discussed, and your comments as to what would be a fair amount from the Department's point of view would be appreciated. The next regular Council meeting will be held on Tuesday, July 3rd, and the last mentioned information should be on hand here prior to that date if possible. As soon as possible after approval has been granted by the Council a requisition will be submitted covering the necessary desks, etc.

In the meantime, might I suggest, that the necessity of an additional teacher, preferably one experienced in teaching higher grades, be kept in mind.

G. Roberts,

AGENT'S REPORT FOR THE QUARTER ENDING DECEMBER 31st, 1945.

During these three months the Dominion Alloy Steel Corporation made some progress on the erection of the Sarnia Council Hall but it was held up because bricklayers could not be obtained. To date (January 15) we are still confronted with this problem. Throughout October, November and December the anger and resentment of the Indians towards the Secretary of the Company steadily increased as they blamed him for delaying the project unnecessarily. The Indians openly advocated taking court action against the Company for breach of contract but this feeling has subsided since Inspector Arnell explained the whole matter to the Indians at a meeting early in January 1946. The Sarnia Band feel that this building must be completed at an early date so that it may be used as a classroom for school children. Mr. McCreath is endeavouring to get bricklayers and if successful the building should be completed in about five weeks. A water main to provide the Council Hall, Mission House, and proposed church was installed and Sarnia Township will supply the water. The residence of the United Church Minister was also supposed to have been moved by the Steel Company and, although the minister vacated the house early last summer, the building was not moved and in October the minister moved back into the house. He is very angry at Mr. McCreath, Secretary of the Company, on account of the above. As this house is owned by the United Church, it is a matter to be settled between the Company and United Church authorities at Toronto.

Memorandum:

ACTING DEPUTY MINISTER

Re: St. Clair Indian Reserve -

EX'D.

On this reserve we have a small day school with accommodation for approximately 40 children. During the academic year 1945-46 approximately 80 children were enrolled, and, as a result, we had to work on the half day system, namely, the children in the junior class attending in the morning and those in the senior classes attending in the afternoon.

We have received very strong representations, both from the Indian Agent and the Council, for the erection of a new school. I thought it necessary to send Mr. Phelan to Sarnia this week to investigate the situation fully, and he spent July 3 and 4 on the reserve and also interviewed the Indian Council. There are prospects of 90 to 106 children requiring educational facilities for the academic year 1946-47, and, under the circumstances, the Indian Agent and the Council feel that we should erect a two-room school. Funds for the purpose will be available in our current year's appropriation. As a matter of fact, we provided the amount required for the erection of a one-room school on this reserve in our 1946-47 appropriation. The additional amount required for the erection of a two-room school will be available.

Owing to the scarcity of lumber, it has been suggested that construction be brick veneer. Brick are easily available.

The services of a competent Indian foreman can also be
secured and most of the labourers employed would be Indians. Materials are available in Sarnia and vicinity but would have to be secured wherever available.

I would appreciate it if the Minister would approve the erection of a two-room school on the St. Clair Reserve and also authorize the purchase of materials required where and when available.

Director.

There are prospects of 90 to 106 children requiring educational facilities for the academic year 1946-47, and, under the circumstances, the Indian Agent and the Council feel that we should erect a two-room school. Funds for the purpose will be available in our current year's appropriation. As a matter of fact, we provided the amount required for the erection of a one-room school on this reserve in our 1946-47 appropriation. The additional amount required for the erection of a two-room school will be available.

Owing to the scarcity of lumber, it has been suggested that construction be brick veneer. Brick are easily available.

The services of a competent Indian foreman can also be
secured and most of the labourers employed would be Indians. Materials are available in Sarnia and vicinity but would have to be secured wherever available.

I would appreciate it if the Minister would approve the erection of a two-room school on the St. Clair Reserve and also authorize the purchase of materials required where and when available.

Memorandum:

DEPUTY MINISTER

Re: St. Clair Indian Day School,
Sarnia Indian Agency,
Electoral District of Lambton West

At the present time we have a one-room school on this reserve, which will accommodate approximately forty pupils. In view of the closing of the Mount Elgin Residential School, a number of children from the St. Clair Reserve who formerly attended that school are now living on the reserve. Enquiries show that within the last two years an additional number of pupils have reached school age. The Indian Agent informs us that school accommodation is urgently required for approximately ninety pupils.

The present building is in poor condition and is not sufficiently large to accommodate the number mentioned above. In the current year's appropriation we provided funds for the erection of a one-room school, but in view of the number of children and the prospects of an increased number in 1947-48, it is considered that a two-room school is absolutely essential. However, due to present conditions, we have not been able to arrange for the erection of other schools provided in this year's appropriation, and consequently funds are available for the erection of the two-room school on the St. Clair Reserve.

I sent the Chief of the Training Division on two occasions during the past four or five weeks in an endeavour to ascertain if the school could be erected by day labour. After making extensive enquiries, both Mr. Phelan and Indian Agent McCracken advised me that owing to present conditions it
is not possible to proceed by day labour and that only one firm in Sarnia was willing to consider the erection of the building. We received a letter from the Shaw Construction Company, dated August 16, which I enclose. It might be inferred from that letter that the company was prepared to erect the school for an amount of $24,000.00. However, to make certain, we phoned to the Indian Agent and requested him to interview the Shaw Construction Company in order to obtain a firm quotation.

Mr. McCracken has written under date of September 4 and, for your information, I enclose a copy of this letter.

In the opinion of our officials, with which I concur, the immediate erection of a two-room school on the St. Clair Reserve is urgently required, and, as the Shaw Construction Company evidently have the materials available and can proceed with the work at once, I enclose Memorandum to Council, which I hope will receive the favourable consideration of the Acting Minister.

Director.

Re: New School, Sarnia Reserve, Your File 29-1-5 (W.T.I).

The plans for the new school show the girls' and boys' toilets to be in the basement with chemical tanks for waste being underneath the floor. These tanks would be cleaned out on either side of the main entrance at the front.

In the opinion of the contractor this arrangement would not be very satisfactory due to the nature of the site which is flat and affords little opportunity for proper drainage. He states that these containers would, in all probability, be inadequate as well as unsanitary.

Some time ago a water pressure line to serve buildings such as the new Council Hall and Mission House was installed. This line traverses the school property and a hook up to serve the school is possible. The water is supplied by Sarnia Township. The line was laid under authority of Departmental letter 31029-1 of October 11th, 1945.

The contractor suggests that flush toilets and a septic tank be installed instead of the arrangement as shown in the plans. If this is done he thinks that the girls' and boys' toilets should be placed in the cloakrooms on the first floor rather than in the basement as this would provide additional elevation. The spaces in the basement originally intended for washrooms could be used as cloakrooms.

Kindly advise at the earliest possible date as to whether the Department approves of the contractor's suggestions or not. In my opinion they sound logical and I recommend that we take his advice.

An immediate reply would be appreciated as the cement for the walls was poured and the contractor will be starting on the basement floor in the near future. As the chemical tanks shown on the plan are under the basement floor it is imperative that we decide what system is to be installed.

With reference to your recent letters regarding the St. Clair School, the following decisions have been made:

(1) Your letter Dec. 24. - Before payments can be made, the Treasury Department require a signed contract. We are preparing this and it will be taken to Sarnia by Mr. Doucet of this Division who expects to visit you about Jan. 22 or 23. (2) Your letter Dec. 31. - The Department approves insulating the walls and ceiling at a cost of $400.00 for material and labour.

(3) Your letter Jan. 6. - As we will probably be obliged to employ an Indian as janitor on a part-time basis, we doubt the advisability of installing a stoker as extreme care has to be exercised so that the stoker will operate efficiently. However, you should consult the contractor and have him obtain prices on an ordinary furnace and also on a furnace with stoker attached. These prices should be submitted to us for our consideration.

(4) Your letter Jan. 4. - The Department approves the action that you have taken in approving the placing of fire insurance on the building while it is under construction. Dear Sir:

An Order in Council of September 12th, 1946, (P.C. 3849) grants authority to engage the Shaw Construction Company of Sarnia, Ontario, to erect a two-room school on the St. Clair Reserve, in the Sarnia Indian Agency, on the understanding that the total expenditure will not exceed $30,000.

I understand that it is now proposed to vary the basis of contract from that of a cost plus fifteen per cent. basis, as originally agreed upon, to that of a firm price of $25,400.

As you are aware, an Order in Council dated February 23rd, 1926, passed under the authority of Sec. 35 of the Public Works Act, transfers to Indian Affairs the power, duty and function of erecting and maintaining buildings required in the service of that branch. It is obvious that in the exercise of this power the Indian Affairs Branch is required to have due regard to all provisions of the Public Works Act which condition such functions.

An examination of the file relating to the above-mentioned undertaking discloses that certain provisions of the Public Works Act were not observed. The following are instances:

(a) Sec. 36 of the said Act provides that tenders shall be invited by public advertisement except under certain conditions, none of which would appear to apply in this case. There is no evidence that this was done.
(b) Sec. 17 provides that no work shall be commenced until a contract has been signed by all parties and the requisite security has been given. At the date of our examination of the fyle, no contract had been signed, nor security provided.

I might observe, too, that the necessary steps to ensure payments for work done also appear to have been neglected as no encumbrance has been raised by your Branch.

As, from the instances cited, the whole procedure in the prosecution of this undertaking would appear to be somewhat irregular, I would appreciate an explanation from you as to why it was considered necessary to depart from standard practice in this particular case.

Yours very truly,

R. G. Hamlyn,
Audit Supervisor, "H" Branch.

With reference to our recent telephone conversation, I enclose herewith copy of a contract with the Shaw Construction Company, Sarnia, Ontario, for the construction of a school on the St.Clair Indian Reserve.

This contract is on a cost plus basis, and was authorized by P.C. 3849 dated September 12, 1946, copy of which is enclosed, and it will be necessary to carry out an audit of the costs of this contract.

Re: Construction of St. Clair School.

I wish to acknowledge receipt of your letter 29-1-5 (WT) of February 28th, 1947 in which you propose sending a cost accountant from Treasury to Sarnia on March 10th.

After inspecting the building and interviewing the company this morning I find that the following is yet to be done:

(1) Installation of furnace, some plumbing and septic tank—the company doing this work (Spiers Sheet Metal) have ordered the furnace and expect it will be delivered this week. If it arrives the installation should not take more than three days. Most of the pipes for plumbing have been installed but wash basins and toilets have not arrived.

(2) Painting both interior and exterior. The exterior cannot be painted till warm weather, possibly six weeks hence, but the company intends to proceed with the interior painting immediately. The tenders which they received re the painting were considered far too high ($1450.00) and the company is endeavouring to secure other tenders as they think not more than $850.00 or $900.00 should be paid for this work.

(3) A drain has to be dug from the basement to the open ditch on the road. This can be done immediately with a compressor, etc., but at greater cost than if it were done at a later date when the frost is out of the ground.

(4) A small portion (about 250 sq. ft.) of flooring remains to be purchased and laid. The company foreman states that this will be completed this week. There is also a small amount of sheet rock to be installed on walls in the basement but this will be completed by the end of the week.

(5) The placing of insul brick siding on the outside. This siding material is on the site and workmen would have started putting it on this morning had the weather been favourable. The company expect it will be completed by the end of the present week.

(6) The blackboards cannot be installed until same are received from the Department. (These were ordered on my requisition of February 3rd, 1947).

The company would like you to send a cost accountant on Monday, March 10th although they readily admit that all work at this school cannot be completed at the same time as the accountant finishes his audit. However they suggest that a reasonable sum be withheld to cover any work not completed at the time of the audit. If the sending of the cost accountant is postponed until all phases of the work have been completed it will definitely not meet with the company's approval.
as they want a substantial progress payment immediately and in this connection I do not think their request unreasonable.

I might add that I will be on vacation from March 10th to March 22nd but I do not expect to leave the city for a few days and I will be available if my services are required by either the accountant or the company.

After reading this report I would appreciate immediate advice as to your decision re sending the accountant. Also please advise if you wish me to reserve hotel accommodation for him.

Indian Agent.

Dear Sirs:

The Department of Mines and Resources, Indian Affairs Branch, advise that they have entered into a contract with you for the construction of a school on the St. Clair Indian Reserve on a "Cost Plus 15% Fee" basis. It is required, concerning such contracts, that an audit of your expenditure and claims for reimbursement be made by a representative of this Division.

The audit will be performed under the direction of our District Supervisor for the area, whose name and address is:

Mr. J. D. Fryer,
District Supervisor,
Cost Inspection & Audit Division,
Office of the Comptroller of the Treasury,
Room 1214, New Wellington Building,
137 Wellington Street W.,
Toronto, Ontario.

He will be in contact with you shortly for the purpose of advising you in detail as to the procedures to be followed by you in accounting and billing for your costs. In the meantime, we give you the following broad outline of essential requirements:

Billings

Recovery of your expenditures will be made by means of a "Progress Certificate", and supporting documents, as per the attached samples. The number of copies required with each submission are as follows:
Billings cont'd.

5 copies of the Progress Claim form 1064
5 copies of Summary of Charges
1 copy of all Payrolls, Suppliers' Invoices and Vouchers
5 copies of Plant Rental Statement
3 copies of Statutory Declaration with final claim.

A supply of form 1064 is being forwarded under separate cover.

Approvals

Purchase requisitions and sub-contracts should be approved by the Indian Agent before purchase or award. All sub-contracts will, in addition to the Indian Agent's approval, also require that of the Director of the Indian Affairs Branch.

Wages and Salaries

Approval will also be required of both the above parties of all wage and salary rates as prevail, or as set, for the particular area in which the construction is being done.

It is our understanding that this work was undertaken when the Regional War Labour Board was functioning and all matters pertaining to wages and salaries paid the rank of foreman, or under, came under their jurisdiction as to remuneration that was to be paid in the various districts or localities throughout the Dominion; therefore, any payments in excess of rates as established by the Board would of necessity require their further approval.

Travelling Expenses

Such claims listing hotel, railway sleeper or parlor car service, should be properly supported by receipts. Expense accounts should show the date of travelling and breakdown of individual meals, viz: breakfast, lunch and dinner. Car mileage or living allowances will also require formal approval of the Indian Agent and the Director of the Indian Affairs Branch.

Plant Rental

Application for approval is required for all plant rental and must also show the name of supplier, description of equipment, rental rate, and whether or not the operator's wages, fuel, and
Running repairs are included in the rental rate. In the case of contractor-owned equipment, make, size or capacity, and its replacement value must also be stated. Such applications for approval will require approval of both parties previously mentioned.

We might state that all applications for approvals should be submitted in five copies through the Indian Agent.

Inventories

Upon completion of the contract, an inventory in five copies is required of all surplus materials, small tools, etc., at laid down prices. Inventories should indicate the date and the disposition of the items, that is, if they were taken over by your firm, sold to other parties, or left in the possession of the Department of Mines and Resources, Indian Affairs Branch.

This Division will be only too pleased to offer cooperation and assistance in every way possible. However, your contract, in delegating responsibility, also imposes upon you certain obligations in relation to the work to be done and the manner of doing it. Your compliance with the foregoing suggestions will result in your progress claims being paid promptly and without difficulty. Please feel free to consult us or our representative at all times.

Yours very truly,

Chief, Construction & Prefinanced Section.

Should the Contractor use or employ, or intend to use or employ, any material, plant, tools, equipment, articles or things, which in the opinion of the Indian Agent, are not in accordance with the provisions of the contract or are in any way unsuitable for the work, or any part thereof, or should the Indian Agent consider that any work is for any reason, improperly, defectively, or insufficiently executed or performed, the Indian Agent may order the Contractor to remove the same, and to use and employ proper material, plant, tools, equipment, articles and things or to properly re-execute and perform such work, as the case may be, and thereupon the Contractor shall immediately comply with such orders and if the Contractor fails to comply with such orders within twenty-four hours the Indian Agent may, at any time thereafter, execute or cause to be executed the orders so given.

10. CONSUMABLE TOOLS, MATERIALS AND SUPPLIES

All usable tools (other than tools customarily provided by tradesmen) and all consumable materials and supplies left over after the completion of the work shall, if the Minister so desires, be taken over and be paid for by the Contractor at a fair and reasonable price to be determined by the Minister.

11. WORK NOT COMPRISED IN CONTRACT

His Majesty may, at any time, without payment therefor, send and employ on, in and about the work other contractors, and workmen, with such horses, machinery, tools, plant, equipment, materials, articles and things as the Indian Agent may deem necessary to do any work not comprised in the contract, and the Contractor shall afford them all reasonable facilities, to the satisfaction of the Indian Agent, for doing such work, the work of the Contractor being interfered with as little as the Indian Agent may deem practicable.
The taking of possession of the whole or any part of the work of the Contractor for such purpose shall not be deemed in acceptance by or on behalf of His Majesty of the whole or any portion of the work comprised in this contract.

12. POWER TO TAKE WORK FROM CONTRACTOR

In case the Contractor shall make default or delay in commencing, or in diligently executing any of the work or portions thereof to be performed, or that may be ordered under the contract, to the satisfaction of the Indian Agent, the Indian Agent may give a general notice to the Contractor requiring him to put an end to such default or delay, and should such default or delay continue for six days after such notice shall have been given by the Indian Agent to the Contractor, or should the Contractor make default in the completion of the work, or any portion thereof, within the time limited with respect thereto in or under this contract, or should the Contractor become insolvent or abandon the work or make an assignment of this contract without the consent required or otherwise fail to observe and perform any of the provisions of the contract, then and in any of such cases, the Minister, for and on behalf of His Majesty, and without any further authorization, may take all the work out of the Contractor's hands and may employ such means as he may see fit to complete the work, and in such cases the Contractor shall have no claim for any further payment on account of the fee stipulated to be payable to the Contractor or in respect of work performed, but shall be chargeable with, and shall remain liable for all loss and damage which may be suffered by His Majesty by reason of such default, or delay, or the non-completion by the Contractor of the work, and all horses, machinery, tools, plant and equipment, and all rights proprietary or otherwise, licences, powers and privileges, whether relating to or affecting real estate or personal property, acquired, possessed or provided by the Contractor for the purposes of the work, or by the Indian Agent under the provision of the contract may be used, exercised and enjoyed by His Majesty, for the purpose of carrying out the work as fully to all intents and purposes as they might theretofore have been used, exercised and enjoyed by the Contractor.

13. INSURANCE

(a) The Contractor, unless otherwise instructed by the Minister, shall insure all materials, equipment and Contractor's plant during transit and at all times during the construction and until the final acceptance of the work and shall keep the same and all buildings and structure being constructed and/or erected insured against loss by fire, in such insurance company or companies and in such amount or amounts as may be approved of by the Indian Agent and the policies of such insurance shall be made payable as the interests of the Contractor and His Majesty may respectively appear, and the original policies together with certified copies thereof shall be forwarded to the Indian Affairs Branch; provided that such buildings or structures need not be insured by the Contractor from and after the date of the occupation thereof by His Majesty.

(b) The Contractor shall maintain such insurance as will protect him from claims under Workmen's Compensation Acts and from any other claims for damages for personal injury, including death, which may arise from his operations under the Contract. Certificates of such insurance shall be forwarded to the Indian Affairs Branch.
and shall be subject to their approval as to adequacy of protection; and the Contractor shall indemnify and save harmless His Majesty from and against all claims and demands, loss, costs, damages, actions suits or other proceedings by whomsoever made, brought or prosecuted in any manner based upon, occasioned by, or attributable to any such death, or injury, or any damage to, or infringement of, any property or right.

14. GOVERNMENT ISSUE

(a) All items comprised in any Government issue supplied to the Contractor for the purposes of the contract shall always be and remain the property of His Majesty and shall be used by the Contractor solely for the purposes of the contract and the Contractor shall account fully to the Minister for such Government issue in such manner as the Minister may require.

(b) The Contractor shall be responsible for and shall indemnify His Majesty for all loss or damage of or to any and all such Government issue while on the premises of or in the care or subject to the control of the Contractor and shall at its own expense replace, repair or restore to the complete satisfaction of the Minister any and all such Government issue which may be so lost or damaged; provided that the Contractor shall not be obligated to make good damage caused by reasonable wear and tear or due to causes beyond his control.

15. PRECAUTIONS AGAINST FIRE

The Contractor shall take special precautions to prevent fire occurring in or about the work, and shall observe and comply with all laws and regulations in force respecting fires, and with all regulations and instructions made and given from time to time during construction, by the Indian Agent with respect to fires and the prevention and extinguishing of fires.

16. ASSIGNMENTS

The Contractor shall not assign or sublet the contract without the written consent of the Minister first obtained; provided however, that (unless, in any case, the Minister objects thereto and subject also as herein provided) the Contractor may sublet such portions of the work herein contracted for as is customary and usual in the construction of such work, but His Majesty shall not in any way be held liable for the payment of any moneys due to any subcontractor, and the Contractor shall be held responsible for the proper performance of every portion of the work herein contracted for.

17. SUB-CONTRACTORS

The Contractor shall, before entering into any sub-contracts for work or materials, notify the Indian Agent in writing of the names of all such proposed sub-contractors and the terms and conditions of such sub-contracts and shall not enter into any such sub-contracts without obtaining the approval of the Indian Agent thereto.

The Indian Agent may, on request, furnish to any sub-contractor wherever practicable, evidence of the amounts certified to on his account.

The Contractor agrees to bind every sub-contractor by the terms of the General Conditions, Drawings and Specifications, as far as applicable to his work.
18. MEMBER OF H. OF C. NOT TO BENEFIT

No member of the House of Commons of Canada shall be admitted to any share or part of the contract, or to any benefit to arise therefrom.

19. ACCOUNTS

The Contractor shall keep proper accounts and records in such form and detail as shall be satisfactory to the Minister of the cost to the Contractor of the work and the invoices, receipts and vouchers relating thereto, and such accounts, records, invoices, receipts and vouchers shall at all times be open to audit and inspection by the Minister or his authorized representatives (who may make copies thereof and take extracts therefrom) and the Contractor shall afford all proper facilities for such audits and inspections and shall furnish the Minister and his authorized representative with all such information as he or they may from time to time require with reference to such accounts, records, invoices, receipts and vouchers. If any part of the work is performed by an allied firm (as defined herein) the Contractor shall also cause such allied firm to keep similar accounts, records, invoices, receipts and vouchers with respect to the cost of the work performed by such allied firm, and to permit the same to be inspected and audited by the authorized representatives of the Minister. The Contractor shall cause all such accounts, records, invoices, receipts and vouchers as aforesaid to be preserved and kept available for audit and inspection at any time and from time to time until the expiration of five (5) years from the date of the termination of the work.

20. WORK TO BE FREE FROM ALL ENCUMBRANCES

Before making any payment on any progress or final estimate the Minister may require the Contractor to furnish evidence that all work performed, and material supplied and all structures built for which payment is being made are free and clear from all lawful claims or liens under any law for labour, workmanship, materials or otherwise; the Contractor shall indemnify and hold harmless His Majesty from and against any and all kinds of claims or liens accruing from labour and services performed and material furnished or otherwise, and any of the same in or about the works.

21. PATENT CLAIMS AND ROYALTIES

(a) His Majesty shall indemnify the Contractor against all actions, claims or proceedings for infringement of any patent or industrial design rights or of any alleged patent or industrial design rights (hereinafter referred to as "patent rights") in carrying out his contract, and for royalties or other payments which may be payable in connection with any such patent rights (including any amounts properly payable by the Contractor to any of its sub-contractors pursuant to any similar covenant of indemnity given by the Contractor to any sub-contractor), in respect of anything the model, plan or design of which shall have been provided by or on behalf of His Majesty, but this indemnity shall apply to this contract only.

(b) Save and except as set forth in sub-section (a) of this section, the Contractor shall indemnify His Majesty against all actions, claims or proceedings for infringement of any patent rights and for royalties or other payments which may be payable in connection with any such patent rights in carrying out this contract.
(c) Before making any payments with respect to any patent rights, the Contractor shall supply to the Minister a statement showing all payments and claims for payment by way of royalties or otherwise which the Contractor or any of its sub-contractors will or may be obligated to make or proposes to make to the owner or holder of any patent rights in connection with this contract, and the basis thereof and the parties to whom the same are payable, and shall from time to time promptly advise the Minister of any and all claims or arrangements made or proposed, which would or might result in further or different payments being made by the Contractor or any of its sub-contractors by way of royalties or otherwise as aforesaid.

(d) If and when the Minister shall so direct, the Contractor shall make no payment by way of royalties or otherwise with respect to any patent rights referred to in any statement furnished by the Contractor as provided in sub-section (e) of this section, except with the consent of the Minister and subject to such conditions as the Minister may impose and from and after the giving of any such direction by the Minister, His Majesty shall indemnify the Contractor against any action, claim or proceeding for infringement of the patent rights covered by such direction or for non-payment of royalties or other payments in respect thereof.

22. SANITATION

The Contractor shall comply with, and the work shall be carried on subject to all regulations made by any lawful authority and applicable to said work, and all orders given by the Indian Agent with respect to sanitation or preservation of health on the work. The Contractor shall make adequate arrangements, to the satisfaction of the Indian Agent, for the medical and sanitary supervision of all his employees.

23. INDIAN AGENT'S MARKS

The Contractor shall protect, and shall not remove or destroy, or permit to be removed or destroyed, the stakes, buoys and other marks placed on or about the said work by the Indian Agent or his assistants, and shall furnish the necessary assistance to correct or replace any stake, buoy or mark which through any cause may have been removed or destroyed.

24. NOTICES

Any notice, order, direction or other communication given to the Contractor under any of the provisions of this contract shall be sufficiently given if delivered to the Contractor personally, or to his foreman, or left at the Contractor's office, or mailed at any post office to the Contractor or foreman addressed to the address mentioned in the contract, or to the Contractor's last known place of business or residence.

25. PROGRESS MEASUREMENTS AND CERTIFICATES NOT BINDING

The progress measurements and progress certificates shall not in any respect be taken as binding upon the Indian Agent or as final measurements or as fixing final amounts; they are to be subject to the revision of the Indian Agent in making up his final certificate, and they shall not in any respect be taken as an acceptance of the work or as a release of the Contractor from responsibility in respect thereof.
26. PROTECTION OF WORK

The contract and all information issued in connection therewith are confidential and their use must be strictly confined to the work and to the purpose of the contract; and particulars contained therein; and other matter issued in connection therewith, must not be disclosed to unauthorized persons.

The Contractor shall at all times take and cause to be taken all reasonable measures, for the protection of the work against espionage and sabotage, and on the order of the Minister shall dispense with the services of any person employed in, about or upon the work or cause the same to be dispensed with. The Minister shall at all times through such agency as he may see fit be entitled to maintain on or about the premises where the work or any part thereof is being carried on such police or other protective force as in the opinion of the Minister may be advisable.

27. CANADIAN WORK AND MATERIALS

To the full extent that the same are procurable, only Canadian labour, parts and materials (unless otherwise agreed by the Minister) shall be used in connection with the work.

27a. EMPLOYMENT OF EX-SERVICE MEN

In engaging labour for the work contemplated by this contract, either from the National Employment Service or from Trade Unions with which the contractor has collective agreements, the contractor shall specify that preference shall be given to competent and available ex-service men.

The contractor shall maintain and keep available for inspection by the Minister a record of the names and addresses of ex-service men employed, together with a record of the steps taken to implement this requirement.

28. SALARIES

The salaries payable to engineers, superintendents, draftsmen and foremen shall only be such as shall be approved by the Minister.

29. TERMINATION

(a) Notwithstanding anything in this contract contained the Minister may, by giving notice to the Contractor, terminate the contract (save and except the provisions of this section and of section 19 of these general conditions) as regards all or any part or parts of the work or works not theretofore completed. Upon such notice being given, the Contractor shall cease work (including the procuring of materials for the fulfilment of the contract) in accordance with and to the extent specified in such notice but shall proceed with all reasonable speed to complete such part or parts (if any) of the work or works as are by the terms of such notice to be completed and shall also proceed with all reasonable speed to complete up to such time and/or stage as may be specified in the notice any part or parts of the work or works as required by such notice. The Minister may, at any time, or from time to time give one or more additional notices with respect to any or all parts of the work which remain to be completed after the giving of any previous notice or notices.

(b) All work completed by the Contractor under or pursuant to the provisions of the contract before or after the giving of any notice, subject to acceptance by His Majesty in accordance with the provisions of the contract, shall be paid for on the basis provided in the agreement (the Contractor being allowed such fraction of his
stipulated fee as shall be proportionate to the amount of the work theretofore completed) and the Contractor shall be entitled to be reimbursed the actual cost to the contractor of work not completed under or pursuant to the provisions of this contract and/or any notice given pursuant thereto plus a fair and reasonable profit in respect of work done thereon, provided that no reimbursement shall be made for materials which have been or may be rejected after inspection as not complying with the terms and conditions of this contract and the specifications.

(c) In the event that the Contractor and the Minister are unable to agree upon the amount in respect of which the Contractor is entitled to be reimbursed as aforesaid, the matter shall be referred to the Exchequer Court.

(d) Whenever practicable the Contractor shall procure materials required for the performance of the contract on terms that will enable it to terminate any contracts entered into by the Contractor upon conditions and terms similar in effect to those herein provided for in respect to termination by the Minister and the giving of a notice or notices as aforesaid; and generally the Contractor shall co-operate with His Majesty and the Minister and do everything reasonably within its power at all times to minimize and reduce the amount of His Majesty's obligations under the provisions of this section.

(e) Upon reimbursement being made to the Contractor as herein provided, title to the materials and/or work in progress in respect of which such reimbursement is made shall pass to and vest in His Majesty (the Contractor hereby agreeing to execute and deliver all requisite instruments by way of further assurance) and such materials and/or work in progress shall be delivered to the order of the Minister, but the materials thus taken over will in no case be in excess of what would have been required for performing the contract in full if no notice had been given under the provisions hereof.

(f) If it is established to the satisfaction of the Minister by the Contractor that by reason of any action taken by the Minister under the provisions of this section exceptional hardship has resulted to the Contractor then the Minister may, notwithstanding any other provisions of this section, in his absolute discretion grant such allowance (not to include in any case, however, any allowance or compensation for loss of profit) to the Contractor as, in the opinion of the Minister is warranted by the circumstances.

(g) Any action, decision or determination by the Minister under the provisions of this section shall be final and binding upon the Contractor.

(h) The Contractor shall have no claim for damages, compensation loss of profit, allowance or otherwise by reason of or directly or indirectly arising out of any action taken or notice given by the Minister under or pursuant to the provisions of this section except as and to the extent in this section expressly provided.

(i) The right of termination and of giving notice hereinafore provided shall be in addition to and not in substitution for any other right possessed by His Majesty and/or the Minister.

30. LABOUR CONDITIONS

The Contractor shall comply with and be subject to all the terms and conditions of the Labour Conditions (if any) referred to in the agreement and to all variations and modifications thereof that may at any time be enacted or brought into force during the continuance of the contract.
SCHEDULE "A"

Definition of work

The 'cost of the work' shall mean and include the reasonable and proper costs and expenses incurred or paid by the Contractor (except with respect to the provisions of Section (j) for the following items only:

Section (a) The total amount actually and properly payable to sub-contractors in connection with the work;

Section (b) Wages of workmen and salaries of engineers, superintendents, draftsmen, foremen, clerical staff, time-keepers and watchmen actually and properly engaged on the work;

Section (c) Cost of materials actually used in the work or required in connection therewith (with the exception of the Government issue) and not included under Section (a) of this Schedule "A";

Section (d) Costs actually and properly incurred for inspection, delivery, installation and removal of materials, plant, tools, and supplies used in connection with the work, it being understood that minimum transportation rates are to be taken advantage of wherever possible.

Section (e) Costs of renting, erecting, maintaining and removing temporary offices, sheds and similar structures actually and necessarily required in connection with the work;

Section (f) Travelling expenses actually and, in the opinion of the Minister, necessarily incurred, in connection with the work;

Section (g) Cost of maintaining and operating the Contractor's plant and equipment actually and properly used in connection with the work and of effecting such repairs thereto as in the opinion of the Indian Agent are necessary for the proper execution of the work exclusive of any repairs which may be necessary because of defects in the plant and equipment when brought to the work;

Section (h) Assessments under any Workmen's Compensation Act, employer's contribution to Unemployment Insurance (if any), premiums actually and properly payable in respect of all insurance policies and bonds, if any, called for by the contract or ordered by the Minister, all royalties actually and properly payable for the use of any patented invention, all fees actually and properly paid for building permits;

Section (i) The cost of all consumable materials, supplies and tools (other than tools customarily provided by tradesmen) actually and properly used in connection with the work;

Section (j) Rental for such power-driven or other plant owned by the Contractor or an allied firm as are actually and properly used in connection with the work or kept in readiness on the work upon the recommendation of the Indian Agent and with the approval of the Minister during the month in respect of which claim for such rental is made, provided that if any of the said items shall be used or kept in readiness as aforesaid for less than a full month then the Contractor shall be paid the pro rata amount thereof; as and when it is decided what items of plant are necessary for completion of the work. Any item of plant which has been brought to the work shall be deemed to be kept in readiness on the work, notwithstanding that such item of plant may be undergoing repairs, provided that the Indian Agent is of opinion that such repairs are required for the proper execution of the work and have not been rendered necessary because of any defect which existed in such item of plant when brought to the work, and provided also that if the time required to effect
such repairs exceeds one month, no rental shall be paid for the time in excess of one month.

Section (k) Amounts actually and properly payable by the Contractor for the rental of power-driven or other plant (not owned by the Contractor or by an allied firm) rented by the Contractor for the purposes of the work, including ordinary maintenance and operating repairs thereon; provided that the Contractor shall previously have advised the Indian Agent that the renting of such plant is necessary to expedite the performance and completion of the work, and provided further that the renting of such plant and the amount of the rental thereof shall have been recommended by the Indian Agent and approved by the Minister for the month or months in respect of which payment of such rental is sought by the Contractor:

Section (l) Bank charges necessarily and properly incurred by the Contractor for the transfer of funds, required for the purposes of the work, from the head office or regularly established branch office bank account (whichever is nearer to the work) of the Contractor to a bank account which the Contractor has opened in the vicinity of the work (hereinafter called the "Work account") including the re-transfer of any funds remaining upon the completion of the work in the work account to the head office or regularly established branch office bank account, provided that in order to keep such charges to a minimum the Contractor will, insofar as possible, deposit in the work account, to be used for the purposes of the work to be performed hereunder, the cheques issued by his Majesty to the Contractor as payment under the provisions hereof which cheques are payable at par at any branch of a chartered bank in the Dominion of Canada;

Section (m) Such other items of cost which have been properly and reasonably incurred by the Contractor solely for the purpose of the work and which have been recommended by the Indian Agent and approved by the Minister provided that in addition to any other item which may not be allowed there shall not be allowed as an item of cost any of the following:-

(1) Allowances for interest on invested capital, bonds debentures, bank or other loans.
(2) Entertainment expenses.
(3) Dues and other memberships other than regular trade associations.
(4) Donations.
(5) Losses on other contracts.
(6) Losses from sale or exchange of capital assets.
(7) Depreciation on buildings, machinery or equipment paid for by the Crown.
(8) Fines and penalties.
(9) Amortization of unrealized appreciation of values of assets.
(10) Expenses, maintenance and/or depreciation of excess facilities.
(11) Increase in reserves for contingencies, repairs, compensation insurance and guaranteed work.
(12) Federal and Provincial income, excess profits or surtaxes.
(13) Unreasonable compensation for officers and employees.
(14) Bond discount or finance charges.
(15) Premiums for life insurance on the lives of officers.
(16) Legal and accounting fees in connection with re-organizations, security issued, or capital stock issues.
(17) Losses on investments, bad debts and expenses of collection.
(18) Advertising and selling expenses.

I suggest that an official from the Training Branch arrange to come to Sarnia when the school is being turned over to us. Actual teaching of vocational training might be delayed until September to enable us to order and install the necessary equipment.

Foreman's daily time reports were checked in detail to the payrolls 100% in order to arrive at the amount of time applicable to this project.

Calculations, extensions and additions have been checked and all adjustments made prior to inclusion in this claim.

The Contractor's payroll shows vacation pay charged at 2% on all classifications employed on the project. Examination disclosed that the contractor did not affix vacation pay stamps to all employees' books.

This amount will be reinstated as an item of cost when the contractor procures Vacation Pay Books and has affixed the correct amount of stamps to each employee's book.

The contractor overlooked some work on the basement floor and I am enclosing sub-contract #11 covering this additional work. One copy should be retained for Departmental file and five copies returned to this office at an early date.

To date most of the work on the school has been completed with the exception of the cement septic tank and levelling of the site. The furnace arrived and has been installed.

I regret to report that when the furnace was lighted one of the pipes leading to the teachers' room became overheated with the result that the building caught fire. Fortunately the fire appeared when workmen were present and it was extinguished. About $100.00 worth of damage was done, but this is covered by insurance and is being repaired. It appears as though the blame lies on inexperienced workmen who installed the furnace.

I expect that it will be at least two weeks before the school is completed and you will be further advised as to the date so that an official from the Training Branch may arrange to come to Sarnia for final inspection.

Re: Construction of St. Clair School,
Your file 29-1-5.

With reference to construction of the new St. Clair School I thought I should inform you as to progress made since my last report of May 10th.

The work has been at a standstill for lack of a pipe to connect the inner and outer septic tanks. This has been on order for some time. Shaw Construction Company has now decided to have this fitting made locally in Sarnia to avoid further delay. It will cost $25.00 or $30.00 more but there seems to be no alternative. We expect the fitting will be ready early next week and then the concrete may be poured and septic tank completed within a few days.

Eavestroughing has also been ordered but has not arrived. The lock for the main door is on order but date of delivery is indefinite. Levelling of the site and laying of a sidewalk from the front gate to the main entrance still has to be completed but this could be done in short order. Obstacles preventing completion of the building are mainly the lack of the septic tank fitting and hardware.

All damage which resulted from the fire has been repaired at the expense of the Insurance Company.

The Shaw Construction Company advise that all of the $30,000.00 will be required to complete the building satisfactorily.

A further report will be submitted with regard to date for final inspection by an official of the Training Branch.

M. W. McCracken,
Indian Agent.
Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources,
OTTAWA, Ontario.

Re: Construction of St. Clair School,
Your file 29-1-5.

Recently the Shaw Construction Company informed me that expenditures already made on the new St. Clair School have exceeded $32,000.00. On numerous occasions during the past two or three months I reminded them that under no circumstances should the $30,000.00 be exceeded. When any decision regarding expenditures was necessary I always pointed out to them that such would be in order providing it would not bring the total cost of the building, when completed, over $30,000.00. This company's bookkeeping system leaves much to be desired and the company itself did not know the amount had been exceeded until very recently.

At the present time the septic tank has been completed and only levelling of the site, erecting flag-pole, building cement steps, and installation of locks in doors remains to be done. The lock for the front door has not yet arrived but a temporary lock is being installed pending delivery of the permanent one. I had intended having eavestroughing and a cement sidewalk from the road to the building but due to the over-expenditure already I do not propose to proceed with these unless approved by the Department.

As the school is practically completed I suggested to the company that they allow the Sr. teacher and Sr. pupils to commence using one of the classrooms. They readily agreed so the Sr. teacher, Mr. Ball, is going to transfer his books, desks, equipment, etc., and begin teaching a full day as from tomorrow, June 12th. This will leave the old St. Clair School available for the Jr. teacher to teach Jr. pupils a full day also. I have instructed the janitor, Basil Grey, to commence duties at the new school as from today. The Jr. teacher is very eager to move into the new building but I am not authorizing same pending final inspection by an official from the Training Branch.

The company is now assembling its records and summarizing expenditures so that Mr. Turley, the Treasury Official from Toronto, may come to complete the audit. In my opinion the proposed final inspection by an official of the Training Branch should be delayed until the audit is finished and a further report re this will be submitted.

M. W. McCracken,
Indian Agent.

Reference your file 29-1-5 (WT).

I wish to acknowledge receipt of your letter of June 18th with reference to audit by Mr. Turley and inspection by an official of the Training Branch.

On receipt of your letter I contacted the Shaw Construction Company. They informed me that they had already written to Mr. Turley in Toronto asking him to come to Sarnia to complete the audit. On Wednesday, July 2nd, Mr. Turley arrived. He found that records of the company were far from complete. This auditor worked from Wednesday till Friday P.M., doing a great deal of work which the company really should have done themselves. He prepared a list of instructions as to what is required to enable him to complete the audit and when the company has complied they are to notify him. Therefore the date of the final audit depends upon the company. The auditor estimates that the $30,000.00 has been exceeded by about $1500.00 or $2000.00.

I think the final inspection by an official of the Treasury Branch could be made at any time convenient to the Department without awaiting the final audit. In my opinion it should be arranged as soon as possible as a number of details such as landscaping, ordering of equipment for manual training and sewing rooms, janitor services, etc. have to be decided. The school is completed as far as actual construction is concerned with the exception of installation of lock on front door and cement step. Delivery of the lock is expected daily.

Would you please advise as to when an official of the Training Branch can come to Sarnia and if you wish me to reserve hotel accommodation I shall do so.

When the new St. Clair School was being built I suggested to the Shaw Construction Company that they erect a new bridge across this drain but when we found that the estimate had been exceeded this work was not performed. On or about October 20th, 1947 the third classroom was opened in the domestic science room in the new St. Clair School. The walls in this room are of cement and it was a difficult and tedious job to install blackboards for the junior teacher who is using this room. Two large slate blackboards were placed on the cement wall at the front of the room and one fibre blackboard was fastened to the side wall. A number of holes had to be drilled by hand through the cement to hold the boards securely. Mr. Williams did this work. While there the teacher requested him to repair some book cases.

Inspector H. B. Galpin made an unofficial visit to this school in December and seemed quite disappointed that there were no sand tables.
in the junior and intermediate rooms. The teachers were very anxious to have the sand tables so I authorized Mr. Williams to build one for each room. He supplied all the materials and labour and each table cost $6.00.

When Colonel Neary visited this school in October he suggested that I hire an Indian to place loose desks in the junior room on wooden runners. Mr. Williams did this work. Enclosed please find voucher #49 for $23.65 in favour of Spiers Sheet Metals, Sarnia, Ontario in payment for repairs to the furnace at the St. Clair Indian Day School on Sarnia Reserve.

The forced draft hot air heating system at this school has caused considerable concern since early last Fall and on former occasions I have found it necessary to have it repaired. Apparently much of the fault lies in the fact that inexperienced janitors have been operating the furnace with the result that it becomes overheated and the fan, which is operated by a motor, refuses to work. I have had electricians and the furnace repair men inspect the entire system with a view to locating the trouble. Recently I had occasion to go to the school late one Sunday night and found that the pulley and belt connecting the motor to the fan had flown off. It was urgent that repairs be made so I called Spiers Sheet Metals as they installed the system originally. They point out that a very dangerous condition with respect to fire exists at this school due to inexperienced firing. This company is of the opinion that someone tampered with the motor and fan with the result that it had to be overhauled.

No doubt you are aware that I have had great difficulty in procuring a janitor for this school as no Indian is anxious for the job. I have a new night lock on the furnace room door so that children and unauthorized persons cannot gain entry and am hoping that the furnace will operate satisfactorily in future. I am not optimistic in this respect as I do not believe any Indian on the Reserve understands the forced draft system of heating. I believe the electricians once again checked the wiring and connections but to date their account has not been received. It will be forwarded at a later date.

I recommend Departmental approval and payment of the enclosed account.
