Re: Fire - St. Clair School,
Sarnia Indian Reserve.

I wish to report in detail regarding the complete destruction of the above-mentioned building by fire on Monday, January 26th, 1948 and concerning which I telephoned Mr. P. Phelan on Tuesday, January 27th. The fire was evidently caused by an overheated furnace and failure of the forced draft system to operate efficiently.

Early in May of 1947 a fire occurred in this building when it was still under construction. At that time two painters were painting the interior of the building and had started a fire in the furnace to help dry the paint. Apparently an area where the hot air pipes pass through the partitions directly above the furnace caught fire and $200.00 damage was done before the two painters put the fire out.

As a result of the above-mentioned fire I had Spiers Sheet Metal of Sarnia check the furnace for defects. I also insisted that one of their men be present when the caretaker started the first fire in the furnace in the Fall. At that time the controls, etc., on the furnace were fully explained to the Indian caretaker, S. F. Rogers. On a few occasions from September to November 18th the classrooms were cold due mostly to inexperienced firing of the furnace by two of the Indian caretaker's boys and the pupils had to be sent home. During this time minor repairs to the furnace and adjustments to the electric motor, fan and controls were performed by Spiers Sheet Metal Company of Sarnia and Chambers Electric Company, also of Sarnia as these were the two companies who had made the original heating and electrical installations. On November 18th Rogers became peevved and resigned as caretaker and Mrs. Basil Gray was appointed. In December and January the classrooms were sometimes too cold to hold classes and the children had to be sent home.

There appeared to be some defect in either the furnace or its electrical connections as on several occasions when a hot fire was put...
on the motor and fan would cease to operate. The teachers would detect an odour of scorched wood and paint and would immediately close drafts etc. When the furnace cooled down the fan would commence normal operation. In December and January Spiers Sheet Metal and Chambers Electric inspected the entire system but they could find nothing wrong. Spiers Sheet Metal and myself suspected that children and unauthorized persons might be tampering with the motor and fan. I mentioned this to Mr. Doucet when he visited St. Clair School on December 10th and he instructed me to install a Yale lock on the furnace room door. This was done in the Christmas holiday period by James R. Williams. The caretaker, Basil Gray, the school principal, Mrs. Williamson and the Intermediate teacher, Mrs. McBracken were given keys to the furnace room. One Sunday night in January I had occasion to go to the school and on inspecting the furnace I found that the belt and pulley on the fan had fallen off. I tried to make emergency repairs and on Monday morning I again had Spiers Sheet Metal Company perform the necessary repairs which entailed a thorough overhauling of the entire heating unit.

On Monday morning, January 26th, 1948 the Intermediate teacher entered her room at 8:45 A.M. and found the temperature to be 38° in her classroom. She and the other two teachers kept the children till 10:30 A.M., but as the temperature had risen to only 42° in one and one-half hours I instructed that the children were to be sent home. At 11:00 A.M. I went to the school. All pupils had gone. I looked at the furnace and a normal fire was burning in the furnace and the fan was operating. I found the bottom draft open about one-quarter of an inch so I closed it and left the school. That afternoon I went to Petrolia re an Indian patient in a nursing home there and then continued on to London to ascertain if a teacher whom I knew there would accept a teaching position in the senior room of St. Clair School. At approximately 11:00 P.M. I arrived home to find the school had burned.

The caretaker stated that about 11:30 A.M. after the children had been sent home she visited the school and put more coal on the furnace, being slightly embarrassed about the rooms being cold. No doubt she opened the drafts at that time, although she denies doing so. In all probability the furnace became overheated and likely the fan ceased operating. Thus the heat was confined, resulting in the gyproc and partitions directly above catching on fire. There was faulty construction and installation as less than eighteen inches existed between the top of the furnace and the gyproc ceiling and walls. At 2:40 P.M. Basil Gray went to the school to tend the furnace and found the school full of smoke which prevented him from entering. He immediately telephoned the fire department in Sarnia as well as Blue...
Water, Polymer and Dow Chemical requesting fire-fighting equipment. The efforts of all of these were to no avail, although they did succeed in saving the teachers' residence which is only a few feet to the rear of the school. Only thirty desks and a few miscellaneous items of school equipment were saved. With the exception of the cement foundation the school is a total loss. Practically all of the credit for saving the residence should go to the Blue Water volunteer brigade. I think they should be reimbursed for their chemicals, coats, rubber boots, etc., used or damaged in the fire and believe Sarnia Indian Council is willing to pay for same from their Band funds.

In my opinion it was very fortunate that the pupils had been sent home as the fire may have gone unnoticed by teachers and some pupils might have been burned to death. If the pupils and teachers had been there they might have detected the overheated furnace as they had on several occasions in the past, but with inexperienced firing and lack of attention on the part of the janitor a disaster would likely have occurred sooner or later. In any case it was undesirable from the standpoint of health to keep pupils inactive in a room 38° to 42° and there was no alternative except to send them home.

I am enclosing picture and clipping taken from the local Sarnia paper in connection with the fire.

On Tuesday morning, January 27th I telephoned the Ontario Provincial Fire Marshall's office in Toronto and requested an investigation as instructed in Departmental telegram. Mr. R. Simmons from the Fire Marshall's office arrived Wednesday morning and conducted an investigation. His report will be forwarded direct to the Indian Affairs Branch at Ottawa.

The loss of this modern, completely equipped four-room school is deeply regretted by myself, teachers, Indian parents and children of Sarnia Reserve. I might mention that our agitating friends, led by Rev. McKenzie and Telford Adams, are doing a great deal of underhand gossiping and have convinced many Indians that the loss of the school was due to the Indian Agent's neglect in not correcting the fire hazard at the school. They also accuse Mrs. McCracken of sending the children home so she could have a holiday. This is very unreasonable as Rev. McKenzie's daughter is one of the teachers and she definitely complained about the cold classrooms and was as ready to go home as anyone else. When Rev. McKenzie visited the school for religious instruction on Friday afternoon, January 23rd, he found the classrooms 61° and instructed that the children should be sent home as it was too cold for classes. The teachers did not comply as he has no jurisdiction.
In the school and they kept the pupils till 4:00 o'clock that day to avoid criticism by Rev. McKenzie.

All matters connected with the fire were discussed in detail with Mr. M. McCrimmon when he visited this Agency on Thursday, January 20th and 30th. At a Band meeting on January 30th the Sarnia Band of Indians passed a resolution agreeing to turn over the basement of their Council Hall for school purposes for an indefinite period at a rental of $15.00 per month. The Department is to supply fuel and pay all expenses re conversion of the basement into two classrooms. Mr. McCrimmon took back with him the estimate of the cost as prepared by James B. Williams, an Indian carpenter of Sarnia Reserve. He states that he can procure all materials and complete the partitioning, etc., in from one to two weeks if authorized by the Indian Affairs Branch.

I understand that all of the twenty-eight pupils in grade one formerly enrolled in Miss McKenzie's room are to remain at home when and if classes are resumed, but would prefer written instructions from the Department on this subject. I strongly recommend that Miss McKenzie be placed in charge of senior pupils, grades five to eight (about twenty pupils) and that Mrs. McCracken teach grades two to four (thirty-one pupils). To lighten Miss McKenzie's teaching duties she might even be relieved of the seven pupils in grade five if the Department considers it advisable. This would leave her only thirteen pupils in grades six to eight. In this connection Mrs. McCracken sent a letter back with Mr. McCrimmon which explains the above more fully.

If two classrooms are to be opened in the basement of the Council Hall we could obtain a sufficient number of used desks (screw down type) from the Sarnia Board of Education at a cost of $1.00 each plus delivery charges.

Four pieces of blackboard each eight feet long and four feet high are required immediately. Three or four broken pieces which were saved from the fire will be used until new ones arrive. With the exception of supplies of grade one pupils all scribblers, books, etc., were destroyed and if it meets with your approval I shall ask the two teachers to submit requisitions for necessary supplies. For this reason an early decision as to the grades to be taught by each teacher is desired.

Sarnia, February 4th, 1948.

I wish to acknowledge receipt of telegram dated February 3rd regarding the remodelling of the basement of the Council Hall to provide two classrooms for St. Clair Indian Day School pupils.

James B. Williams was immediately notified to commence work and he expects to have it completed within a few days, possibly by Saturday, February 7th.

Would you please forward an accountable advance cheque for $262.00 at the earliest possible date so that Williams and the men working on the job can be paid?

Only two small pieces of blackboard were salvaged from the fire. These will be entirely inadequate for two classrooms. Mr. Williams suggests that sixty-four square feet of masonite be purchased and painted with black Duco paint. He is of the opinion that the painted masonite would serve for blackboards. The masonite would cost about $30.00 and the labour of painting and installing same would be about $10.00, making a total expenditure of $40.00 for blackboards. This $40.00 was not included in Williams' tender which Mr. McCrimmon took back to Ottawa with him. If the blackboards are ordered through the stationery office in the regular way there might be a long delay and as they are urgently needed I recommend that authority be granted to purchase the masonite locally and have Mr. Williams paint and install the boards as suggested above.

When the fire occurred on January 26th there was about two tons of coal in the St. Clair School. In the process of fighting the fire the coal became wet and frozen. A considerable quantity of it is embedded in ice in the basement. Eventually most of it will be salvaged and can be used in the teachers' residence. It was impracticable to shovel this coal from the basement of the school to a truck and transport it to the Council House and as coal is needed in the Council House when school starts next week I ordered two tons from the Century...

I wish to refer to your letter No. 29-1-5 (E.1) of February 3rd regarding temporary classrooms in connection with the Sarnia Council Hall for St. Clair Indian Day School pupils.

Mr. James B. Williams commenced the alterations on February 5th. They are now practically completed and it would be possible to open the classrooms on Wednesday if we had desks and blackboards. About sixteen desks were salvaged from the senior room, and we have located four others which will be suitable for the larger pupils. Therefore no additional desks are required for the senior classroom. All desks in the intermediate room, grades two to four inclusive, were destroyed by fire but a number were saved from the junior classroom which are large enough for small grade two pupils. Approximately twenty medium sized desks for pupils in grades two to four are required at the moment. I have already written requesting authority to purchase used desks from the Board of Education in the city of Sarnia. I have also written regarding purchasing of Masonite and painting it as a substitute for blackboards. If authority to purchase the desks and blackboards is received we could resume classes the next day.

Immediate advice as to which teacher is to have charge of the senior classroom is requested. If we knew this the senior room could be opened immediately as we have enough desks and pieces of blackboard to proceed on a temporary basis. I might mention that the senior teacher, Mrs. M. Williamson, submitted her resignation to take effect on January 31st and no further salary cheques should be issued in her favour.

Mrs. McCracken has submitted a requisition covering supplies for the two classrooms, but an immediate supply of scribblers, etc., will have to be obtained and I intend to purchase these locally up to a maximum of $30.00. I may find it necessary to borrow some supplies.
from Kettle Point School and trust that this will meet with your approval.

"Moved by Alfred Rodd, seconded by Fred Rogers that the basement of the Council Hall be made available for school purposes, for an indefinite period." Carried.

"Moved by Telford Adams, seconded by Leonard Plain that the Band accept Fifteen Dollars ($15.00) per month for rental of the Hall to the Indian Department." Carried.

RE: Ipperwash Camp

I have noted on the plan lent me by the Trust Branch the number of the buildings available to the Indian Affairs. They are Nos. 11, 12, 13, 14, 41, 44, 45 and 46. No. 11 is a salvage shed, well constructed on a cement floor, it is 20' x 60'. Nos. 12, 13 and 14 are H. Huts. No. 12 is intact but Nos. 13 and 14 have been partly dismantled.

The inside Gyprock and insulation have been removed. The hot water heating system and plumbing are intact. There is very good material left in 13 and 14 which could be used to advantage. These huts are 24' x 120'.

No. 41 is the Dental Clinic and would be very practical as classrooms. It is 24' x 70'.

The problem is to find out if these buildings can economically be transported. If so, one might be set on the present foundation of the burnt school.

A second plan would be to rebuild the school from material available from the camp. Considerable material of the school is usable in its present shape. The beams appear sound as well as the joists, the sub floor and some walls.

I would suggest that immediate steps be taken to investigate the cost of transporting these buildings should it prove to be feasible.
I would also suggest that Mr. McCracken be notified to put up posters forbidding any person entering the burnt school as considerable danger exists. Decision on what is to be done is urgent as special attention is necessary to the conditions of the salvage.

A.J. Doucet.

I, HERBERT L. PLAIN, submit my tender for the dismantling and salvaging all usable material of the St. Clair Indian School for eleven hundred (1100.00) dollars.

I wish to acknowledge receipt of your letter 29-1-5 (E.1) of March 24th, 1948 re cost of dismantling and salvaging St. Clair School.

The two white men interviewed by Mr. Doucet recently when he visited Sarnia were Mr. Jack Verbeem, 108 Alfred Street, Point Edward, Ontario and Mr. Tracy Torrance, Errol Road, Sarnia, Ontario.

I have discussed the matter with Mr. Verbeem. He states that when his tender for $600.00 was submitted late in February there was about eight inches of ice in the basement. He intended to commence work early in March before the ice melted. At that time the ice could have been chopped with an axe and thrown out with a shovel which would not have cost very much. Now the ice has melted and with Spring rains, etc., there is twenty inches of water in the basement. When dismantling begins this water will have to be pumped out and once the basement is free of water it should be kept dry by a sump pump or else it will simply fill up again as there is very poor drainage on the school site.

When the school was built a sump pump operated by a three horse power electric motor was installed. This pump was damaged by firemen and the pump as well as the electric motor were frozen in the ice in the pit. They are still there. The condition of the motor cannot be determined until it is disconnected and examined. There is a possibility that a new motor will be required or extensive repairs made to the old one. A power line from the electric wires presently serving the teachers' residence will have to be built and switches, etc., installed to operate the sump pump.

Mr. Verbeem estimates that the cost of pumping out water presently in the basement and repairs to the pump and electric motor, hydro line, switches, etc., will be about $100.00. This will bring his tender up to $700.00 rather than the previously quoted figure of $600.00.
I have also discussed the dismantling of the school with James B. Williams, an Indian, who previously submitted a tender for $1120.00. I told him that white men were willing to take a contract at $700.00. He is not interested in doing the work for this amount. He maintains that his figure of $1120.00 is reasonable if the Department wishes a careful and satisfactory salvage job performed. He states that the remains of the building could be wrecked in short order if no particular care is taken re salvage. He expressed the opinion that very little would be salvaged by white men at the $700.00 figure. Williams seemed a bit peeved when I informed him that other members had been invited to tender. First of all he said he would withdraw his tender entirely, but later reconsidered and is now willing to do it for $972.00 as per the enclosed tender.

Two other members of the Band were interviewed re dismantling the school. One of them, Albert Oliver, would have been competent to do the work but he finally decided not to submit a tender. The other Indian, Leonard Plain, has submitted the enclosed tender for $1100.00. I am doubtful as to whether or not this man is quite capable of doing the work satisfactorily and furthermore he does not appear to be particularly anxious for the job. He is a veteran of the 1939 war and a bricklayer by trade, but has not had much experience.

In my opinion James B. Williams would do a satisfactory dismantling and salvaging job. He dismantled and salvaged materials from the Indian Church on Sarnia Reserve in 1945 and everyone was satisfied with his work on that project.

James B. Williams is one of the present Councillors of Sarnia Band. He intends to use the Band granary adjacent to the site to store materials salvaged from the school, but if the two white men are given the contract Williams will likely persuade the Sarnia Council to refuse to allow the white men the same privilege, yet if the salvage remains outside it will gradually disappear. In his original tender Williams included $50.00 to be paid to the Band for the use of the granary to store school materials. This fact will give you some idea of the greed and hostile attitude of most of the Sarnia Indians who expect payment from the Training Branch for everything connected with the school when it is being provided, at no expense to the Band, to teach their children.

With the above information I trust that the Department will be able to make a decision re dismantling and salvaging what remains of the St. Clair School.

M. W. McCracken
Superintendent, Sarnia Indian Agency.

Re: Water Supply,
St. Clair School and Teachers' Residence.

Under authority of Departmental letter 31029-1 of September 11th, 1946 a contract was approved whereby Sarnia Township agreed to supply water to public buildings on Sarnia Reserve. The St. Clair Indian Day School, St. Clair Teachers' Residence, Sarnia Indian Council Hall and United Church buildings have been provided with city water.

Last January the new St. Clair School was destroyed by fire. At that time there was only one shut-off to serve the new school and teachers' residence. Emergency arrangements had to be made to shut the water off after the fire in the new school and considerable inconvenience resulted as water was still necessary in the St. Clair Teachers' Residence.

Sarnia Township Water Commissioner decided that separate shut-offs were required for the new St. Clair School and the St. Clair Residence. They overlooked notifying me that this work was necessary until after it was performed and the account in the amount of $29.27 was received. Their employees had to excavate down to the water main and install the two shut-offs. In my opinion this work was necessary to avoid confusion in the water supply to these two buildings in future years. The Water Commissioner regretted that he did not inform us that he intended to do this work but I recommend that it be considered an emergency and that the Department approve of payment.

Dear Colonel Neary:

As requested by you, - accompanied by T.J. Rispin a trip was made to Sarnia and Camp Ipperwash to look over the feasibility of moving a building from the Camp to the Sarnia Reserve.

The following comment is forwarded for your information.

The dental building which apparently has been selected to replace the burned-out school building, is considered most suitable in every way for the purpose intended, as it is in first class shape.

With the exception of the removal of a few partitions, it can readily be made into two excellent school-rooms.

It is about six feet shorter than the burned-out building, but fortunately the centre of that building, having the teachers' room on one side and the main entrance on the other, was not too badly damaged, and could easily be rebuilt from what is salvaged.

Consequently, as the Camp building will almost certainly have to be cut in two to permit removal, - as, as a single unit it is too long to permit making necessary road turns, - the two cut ends could be hoisted on to the existing walls and joined to the aforementioned centre, and thus make a complete two-roomed school, along the lines it was before the fire.

In addition, the Camp building has an outside measurement of 24 feet, whereas the burned building was only 23 feet. This factor will be an advantage in most ways, but will entail a false wall and the extension of the windows on the side farthest from the road.

In Rispin's opinion the building of the false wall and the extension of the windows was not a difficult task using lumber, and was preferable to thickening the present wall with concrete, or the forcing of it out a foot, - which also is apparently possible, but not easy.

TO HIS EXCELLENCY

THE GOVERNOR GENERAL IN COUNCIL,

The undersigned has the honour to report:

THAT it is immediately necessary, and funds are provided in the 1948-49 estimates, Indian Affairs Branch, Mines and Resources, to provide a three-room Indian Day School on the St. Clair Indian Reserve, Sarnia Indian Agency in the Province of Ontario;

THAT it is essential that educational facilities be provided for the Indian children on the St. Clair Indian Reserve;

THAT Section 36 of the Public Works Act, Chapter 166, R.S.C. 1927, provides, in part as follows:

"Whenever any works are to be executed under the direction of any Department of the Government the Minister having charge of such Department shall invite tenders by public advertisement for the execution of such works except in cases (a) of pressing emergency in which delay would be injurious to the public interest...";

THAT due to the high building costs, it has been decided not to erect a new school but to move a surplus Army building from the Ipperwash Army Camp and erect it as a school on the foundations of the old building. That a competent building contractor, namely, Mr. Tracy Terrance, M.H., 2, Sarnia, Ontario, is to undertake the moving of this surplus Army building, to build in the centre section required, to remodel the building to provide three classrooms, a teachers' room, and wash rooms for the sum of $7,200.00.

THAT it is considered that the provision of this school is a pressing emergency and within the exception provided in Section 36 above recited and further, it is considered that the work can be more expeditiously and economically executed as suggested herein.

The undersigned, therefore, recommends that authority be granted for the acceptance of this tender in the amount of $7,200.00 which after making provision for contingencies would involve an expenditure of $5,000.00.

Respectfully submitted,

Minister of Mines and Resources.

St. Clair Indian Day School.

As you will recall, the two-room school on this Reserve near Sarnia was partially destroyed by fire last winter.

It was found that Building 41 at this Army Camp would fit almost exactly on the cement foundation of the old school. Since that time we have carried on negotiations with the Department of National Defence for the release of this building. It will be necessary to cut the Army building in half, jack up the half, move it onto the hauling equipment, pull it some forty miles when the necessary permission is obtained for the lifting of hydro wires, etc., and then hoist it onto the existing foundation. I wish to acknowledge receipt of your letter 29-1-5 (E.2) of September 18th, re the military building to be transferred to Sarnia and remodelled for St. Clair School purposes.

In a telephone conversation with Mr. Doucet this morning I was asked to find out how long it would take to procure a moving permit from the Ontario Department of Highways and also the cost of same. I had a personal interview with Mr. Hagen, the mover, this afternoon. He has been moving buildings in this locality for many years and assured me that he could get the necessary permit in a few hours and at no time has there been a delay of more than forty-eight hours in obtaining moving permits. He also stated that the cost would certainly not exceed $30.00. Mr. Hagen will possibly be ready to start preparing the building at Ipperwash for moving about September 29th. In any event he promises to commence work on the building preparatory to moving not later than October 4th. He estimates that it will take from one to two days to load the building and therefore it will no doubt arrive at the St. Clair School site on Sarnia Reserve toward the latter part of the week commencing October 4th. I trust that the above is the information which Mr. Doucet requires.

I also saw Mr. Torrance, the building contractor who submitted an estimate on the dismantling of the old school and remodelling the new one. His tender was submitted under cover of my letter of July 16th, at an estimated cost of $7200.00. I regret very much to inform you that Mr. Torrance made a very bad error when figuring the cost of this project. I only learned of it this afternoon. The $7200.00 does not include the cost of moving. In other words the total estimated expenditure should be $8400.00. Mr. Torrance explained the
matter by telling me that his wife compiled the cost and when totalling same she omitted to include $1200.00 for moving. Mr. Torrance discovered his error last Sunday, September 19th. He hesitated to mention it to me as he realized the seriousness of his error. I advised him that a submission had already been made to the Minister for approval of the contract at $7200.00. We discussed the matter at length and decided that now is the proper time to bring it to your attention rather than have a dangerous misunderstanding later on. This builder did not definitely refuse to sign a contract at the $7200.00 figure but if forced to proceed for this sum we would no doubt be confronted with an unfinished or very poorly constructed building. I had a long talk with Mr. Torrance and I believe he is quite honest when he says that his wife forgot to include the $1200.00. He is sincere and is greatly perturbed over the whole affair. He does not want to proceed on the basis of doing the work for $7200.00 as he frankly admits that he could not do anything but a cheap job for this figure. As above-stated I deeply regret the circumstances leading to this perplexing situation. I mentioned to Mr. Torrance that it might be possible to make an adjustment when Mr. Doucet arrives. However, in my opinion, it would be wise to request a further $1200.00 to cover the moving contract as I consider that even at $8400.00 we would get a good school at a reasonable price.

I have told Mr. Torrance to continue dismantling the burned-out school so that it will be ready for the military building when it arrives at Sarnia. I also instructed Mr. Hagen to proceed with his part of the work. If you wish Mr. Torrance and Mr. Hagen to cease all work until the money complications mentioned above have been clarified kindly wire me to this effect.

M. W. McCracken,
Superintendent, Sarnia Indian Agency.
Certified to be a true copy of a Minute of a Meeting of the Committee of the Privy Council, approved by His Excellency the Governor General on the 22 September 1943.

The Committee of the Privy Council have had before them a report dated 8th September, 1943, from the Minister of Mines and Resources, representing:

THAT it is immediately necessary, and funds are provided in the 1943-44 estimates, Indian Affairs Branch, Mines and Resources, to provide a three-room Indian Day School on the St. Clair Indian Reserve, Sarnia Indian Agency in the Province of Ontario;

THAT it is essential that educational facilities be provided for the Indian children on the St. Clair Indian Reserve;

THAT Section 36 of the Public Works Act, Chapter 166, R.S.C., 1927, provides, in part as follows:

"Whenever any works are to be executed under the direction of any department of the Government the Minister having charge of such Department shall invite tenders by public advertisement for the execution of such works except in cases (a) of pressing emergency in which delay would be injurious to the public interest..."

THAT due to the high building costs, it has been decided not to erect a new school but to move a surplus Army building from the Ipperwash Army Camp and erect it as a school on the foundations of the old building;

THAT a competent building contractor, namely, Mr. Tracy Terrance, B.A., #2, Sarnia, Ontario, is to undertake the moving of this surplus Army building, to build in the centre section required, to remodel the building to provide three classrooms, a teachers' room, and wash rooms for the sum of $7,200.00;

THAT it is considered that the provisions of this school is a pressing emergency and within the exception provided in Section 36 above recited and further, it is considered that the work can be more expeditiously and economically executed as suggested herein.

The Committee, therefore, on the recommendation of the Minister of Mines and Resources, advise that authority be granted for the acceptance of the aforesaid tender in the amount of $7,200.00 which, after making provision for contingencies, would involve an expenditure of $8,000.00.

I wish to refer to recent telephone conversation which I had with Colonel Neary with regard to the release of #41 Military Building at Camp Ipperwash.

On Monday, September 13th I met one of the military officials at Camp Ipperwash and the release of the building to us was effected as per the enclosed "Certificate of Hand-Over". At the same time I was advised by the military officials that the building could be moved from the camp immediately.

I have contacted Mr. Tracy Torrance and advised him that the building now belongs to the Indian Affairs Branch and the project of moving it to Sarnia can be undertaken. Mr. Hagen, the mover whom Mr. Torrance is engaging will be prepared to move the building in approximately two weeks from this date. Mr. Torrance has commenced preparing the site so that it will be ready to receive the building. He has pumped the water out of the basement and is now having the sump pump and electric motor repaired. He intends to commence dismantling what remains of the structure in the very near future. I cannot tell at the moment just when would be most opportune for Mr. Doucet to come to Sarnia but expect that the project will be commenced in about two weeks at which time I would appreciate his assistance. During the course of the next two weeks I shall write you regarding further progress which we expect will have been made so that Mr. Doucet may prepare to come to Sarnia.

In my letters of July 6th and July 16th I pointed out that the boiler and heating jacket had been removed from Military Building #41 and I suggested that an effort be made to persuade the Military to release a furnace boiler and jacket. Memorandum:

ACTING DIRECTOR,

Re: Sarnia Indian Day School Superintendent.

Mr. Doucet, our Supervisor of Vocational Training, is a practical builder of many years' experience. On many occasions we have taken his advice concerning small building problems and have always found it to be sound. Please find attached a report submitted to me by him concerning a telephone conversation which he had yesterday with Mr. Indian Superintendent McCracken, of the Sarnia Superintendency.

Mr. Phelan, Mr. Doucet and I discussed at some length the problem of heating this building. In view of a clearly stated government policy with regard to the use of oil burners and oil burning furnaces, it was decided to install a stoker type furnace. It would seem evident that Mr. Morris has decided to change our instructions in this regard.

Mr. Doucet also recommended that the roof on the Army building (which has been moved to Sarnia for use as a classroom) would be good for several years yet. Mr. McCracken now states that he has been instructed by Mr. Morris to replace the present roof by asphalt shingles.

An Order-in-Council has been passed providing for the acceptance of a tender by Mr. Terrance. If Mr. Morris is to be permitted to visit our school building projects in the field and to countermand the orders and instructions given by staff of this Division, then confusion and dissatisfaction is bound to result.

In conclusion, may I add that never during Mr. Arneil's tenure of office in Ontario was it necessary to draw to Mr. Hoey's attention any interference of this nature.

Bernard F. Neary,

Re: Heating Unit - St. Clair Indian Day School.

Attention: Mr. Doucet.

Enclosed please find estimate of cost prepared by the Calcott Plumbing Company covering heating requirements at St. Clair School.

You will note that a forced air heating system with an oil burner and 500 gallon underground storage tank would cost $2600.00. If an oil burner were installed we are reasonably certain that an oil contract could be procured.

In the school which was destroyed by fire the heating unit was a hand fed forced draft hot air system. It was installed by Spiers Sheet Metal Company of Sarnia at a cost of $890.00, but the furnace was about 24" whereas the Calcott Plumbing Company recommend a much larger furnace (about 35") for $2000.00.

The Calcott Company is one of the best and largest heating and plumbing contractors in Sarnia. They are prepared to supply and completely install the heating unit in the school as per the enclosed tender, providing they are not bound down to any time limit. This is understandable in view of the present scarcity of heating units and furnace materials as well as experienced help.

I am endeavouring to secure an estimate of cost of a completely installed heating unit from the Sarnia Heating & Electric Company and expect that it will be available the latter part of next week. It will be forwarded to the Department when received. I imagine their figure will be about the same as that of the Calcott Plumbing Company.
The contractor, Mr. Torrance, has made good progress in joining the two portions of the building. He has repaired the roof, put on the insul brick siding, altered the windows and painted the outside woodwork. In other words the project is sufficiently advanced to have another inspection by Mr. Doucet at which time he could give us further instructions regarding heating, plumbing and interior work.

As soon as possible arrangements should be made to pay Mr. Torrance, the contractor, the initial sum of $3000.00 as detailed in his tender. To date he has not signed any contract.

I might add that the Chief and Council on the insistence of agitator Telford Adams and Reverend McKenzie are still demanding that rear or side exits for pupils in each classroom be provided. They are not satisfied to rely on children escaping through windows in case of fire and at a recent meeting of the Band the following resolution was passed:

"It was moved by Calvin Adams and seconded by Albert Oliver that the Band request the Department to install a rear exit or fire escape in the new school house now being erected on the Reserve."

Carried.

Re: St. Clair Indian Day School.

I visited St. Clair Indian Day School this morning and found that the contractor, Mr. Torrance, has made good progress on the alterations. All of the outside work such as joining the two portions of the building, roofing, painting, cement work on the overhang, insul brick and cleaning up debris has been completed. The old partitions have been dismantled and a start has been made on the new partitions. Windows have been transferred and refitted to procure uniformity. Original windows on the ends and one side have been taken out and the openings recovered to form a solid wall. The sump pump has been repaired and is now being operated to keep the basement dry. All windows in the basement have been replaced with new ones. The existing hot water pipes have not been moved or disconnected pending a decision re the type of heating to be installed.

I pointed out to him that
he would likely have to sign a contract before any payment could be made so perhaps Mr. Doucet could bring the contract the next time he comes to Sarnia. It would appear advisable to have Mr. Doucet come to Sarnia in approximately two weeks from this date to go into matters pertaining to heating, plumbing, etc. as well as details re contract to be signed by Mr. Torrance.

You are aware that Miss Jean Morris commenced duties as intermediate teacher at St. Clair School in September, 1948. Miss Morris previously taught at Muncey where she enjoyed the use of the teachers' residence attached to the #1 Oneida School. When she transferred to Sarnia she was under the impression that the St. Clair teachers' residence would be available for her use. The Principal of the school, Mr. Dodson, took up residence in the St. Clair teacherage. He was not in favour of providing a room in the residence for Miss Morris and in a telephone conversation which I had with Colonel Neary I was advised that the St. Clair residence was for the Principal and Miss Morris had no claim respecting its use.

Miss Morris secured accommodation with the local minister, Reverend C. W. McKenzie. He is charging her the ridiculous sum of $14.00 per week. Similar accommodation in the city of Sarnia could be procured for $10.00 to $12.00. Miss Morris would like to move from Mr. McKenzie's place as she finds him very difficult. She mentioned the matter of accommodation to Mr. Doucet and requested that the Department assume responsibility for payment of a portion of her housing expenses. I am in
favour of granting her a monthly allowance of possibly $25.00, but I do not think that the Department should pay anything as long as this teacher stays at Mr. McKenzie's place. In all probability he would increase her rate of board when he found out that the Department was giving her an allowance.

Miss Morris is trying to locate a small apartment or rooms with kitchen privileges and if she is successful I recommend that she be granted up to $25.00 a month to defray rental costs.

Attention: Mr. A. J. Doucet,

I wish to acknowledge receipt of "Contract Agreement" for $800.00 which you forwarded for signature of Mr. Tracy Torrance.

On December 13th I interviewed Mr. Torrance and he signed the Contract. He also gave me a certified cheque for $800.00, being the 10% deposit. It was with considerable hesitation that he agreed to sign as he did not entirely approve of article 1 on the bottom of page 1 in the Agreement. I gave him official receipt No. D76065 for the $800.00 payment. At 9:00 o'clock on the morning of December 14th Mr. Torrance appeared at this office and requested that the Contract be not forwarded to the Department as he was not entirely satisfied with it in its present form. He stated that he would be able to finance the project if I refunded the $800.00. It appeared advisable for me to do so and I returned the cheque to him and cancelled the receipt.
Mr. Torrance is now attending to the plumbing and electrical work. He expects to have same almost completed the latter part of January, 1949. He suggests that Mr. Doucet defer his visit until that time. I think Mr. Torrance will be quite willing to sign the Contract but before doing so he wishes to have Mr. Doucet inspect the building and discuss the matter personally with him. His original tender was for $7200.00 which did not include moving. The moving costs of $1200.00 along with an estimated $300.00 for permits brings the total to $8700.00. The mover, Mr. Hagen, is refusing to pay the cost of the permits which leaves a deficit of $700.00. To make up part of this Mr. Torrance would accept the twelve radiators which will not now be used in the school building. This contractor is sincere and is very anxious to do satisfactory work on the building. I do not anticipate any major complications, but as above stated Mr. Torrance would like a personal interview with Mr. Doucet before signing any Agreement. I therefore recommend that matters remain as they are until the latter part of January and suggest that Mr. Doucet endeavour to come to Sarnia at that time. I might add that as of this date Mr. Torrance and I estimate that 75% of his Contract has been completed.

for St. Clair School purposes.

When this project was commenced I was under the
impression that Mr. Tracy Torrance was granted the contract
and that he sublet the moving portion to Mr. Hagen for
$1200.00. I was present when Mr. Hagen and Mr. Torrance
arrived at this figure. Both Mr. Torrance and myself
believed that the $1200.00 figure included cost of all
permits such as highway, railway and expenses re moving
of telephone and hydro wires. Mr. Torrance and I considered
requesting the mover, Mr. Hagen, to sign an Agreement, but
he did not appear anxious for the job and we thought that
he might refuse to do the work if we insisted on having
him sign any papers. Therefore no signed contract between
this office and Mr. Hagen nor between Mr. Torrance and Mr.
Hagen was prepared.

When the moving was completed Mr. Hagen requested
Mr. Torrance to pay the cost of all permits and wire moving
in addition to the $1200.00 which makes a total of approx-
imately $1500.00 rather than $1200.00. Mr. Torrance refused
and nothing was done in the matter until about two weeks
before Christmas. Mr. Hagen then visited this office and I
was successful in having him sign a document to the effect
that he would accept $1300.00 in full payment for moving the building. Mr. Torrance is satisfied and the matter has been amicably settled.

I trust that the above explanation and proposed settlement meets with the approval of the Department.

I wish to refer to my letter of February 5th, 1948 with regard to an account for $66.50 from the Blue Water Fire Department in connection with the fire which destroyed the St. Clair Indian Day School on Sarnia Reserve. In the same letter you will note that I forwarded a copy of a Council resolution in which they recommended that the Training Division at Ottawa pay the Blue Water Fire Department the sum of $200.00. I do not appear to have received a reply to my letter, although I think I recall mentioning it to Mr. Doucet on one of his trips to Sarnia Agency and as I remember he stated that the matter of paying the account was still under consideration.

At the regular monthly Council Meeting of Sarnia Band held on May 3rd, 1949 the Chief presented the enclosed letter which he had received from the Blue Water Rate Payers' Association. In this letter you will note that the Association is requesting a donation from Band funds to reimburse the Blue Water Fire Department. The Chief and Council are somewhat annoyed because the Training Division had not seen fit to pay the Blue Water Fire Department. In the course of the discussion they pointed
out that if a fire occurred on the Reserve the Blue Water Fire Department would refuse to render any assistance because they had not been paid for fighting the school fire. Eventually the Council decided that it would be in the best interests of the Band if a donation were made from their funds and the following resolution was passed:

"Moved by James B. Williams, seconded by Albert Oliver that a contribution of One Hundred Dollars from Band funds be made to the Blue Water Volunteer Fire Department."

Carried.

The Chief and Council pointed out that the recommendation to make a donation of $100.00 from Band funds should not be construed to mean that the $66.50 is to be ignored by the Training Division. In other words they expect the Training Division to pay $66.50 in addition to the $100.00 donation from Band funds.

As no provision for a grant of this nature from Band funds was made in the Sarnia budget for 1949 I presume that a Council resolution form I.A. 514 should be forwarded if the resolution is approved. Would you therefore kindly advise if the resolution meets with favourable consideration, and if so I will then procure and forward the necessary I.A. 514 form at the June meeting of the Council.

M. W. McCracken,
Superintendent, Sarnia Indian Agency.

Enc.
Chief Kenneth Plain,
Indian Reserve,
SARNIA, Ontario.

March 17, 1949

Dear Sir:

I am instructed by the committee of the Blue Water Ratepayers Association to write you asking for a contribution towards the upkeep of their fire brigade. This brigade is maintained by voluntary contributions and entertainments.

In the effort to put out the fire at the school on the 26th January, 1948, 3 rubber raincoats & 3 pairs of rubber boots were destroyed. Also 12 fire extinguishers were used. Under the circumstances, we would be pleased if you would be kind enough to let us have a donation to help us pay our expenses.

Yours very truly,

BLUE WATER RATEPAYERS ASSOCIATION.

H. Nelson
Secretary.

Enclosed please find voucher #305 in favour of Tracy Torrance in the amount of $45.00 for raising the flag pole at the new St. Clair School on Sarnia Reserve.

When the work of building the first St. Clair School was done by Shaw Construction Company they placed the flag pole in front of the school. In lowering and raising it this company had bent the flag pole and had to heat it with electric torches to straighten the pole. It had not been painted for years, but the Shaw Construction Company nevertheless erected it. They also neglected to install a pulley at the top so that the flag could be raised and lowered.

When the second St. Clair School was being officially opened it was necessary to take the flag pole down, scrape off the old paint, repaint it, purchase rope and pulleys and then raise the pole. It would have presented a very unsightly appearance if this work had not been done before the official opening. An Indian named James B. Williams quoted a price of $60.00 for the flag pole work. However, I got the contractor who built the school, Mr. Torrance, to perform the same satisfactorily for $45.00 which includes labour as well as rope, pulleys, etc.

Re grants for teacherage, Sarnia Reserve.

Dear Mr. Neary,

School is over and partitions in hall are down. Hope to take up flooring next week. This material is to build garage and part of verandah for teacherage. You will recall the Dep't paid $100.00 for lumber for garage. I purchased the remainder from Mr. Morrance to get material for a verandah. This is much needed as a protection for the front door. The storm door has already been blown from our hands and broken. The verandah will be a saving on fuel as well. This was evidenced at Moraviantown when we enclosed the front open verandah.

This week we had 40 loads of top soil brot in for foundation of a garden on the West side of teacherage, on the driveway leading to garage and for foundation of a lawn on north side of house. We hope to level off for grass, leaving a sloping side on the north edge where we expect to have a rock garden. From this there will have to be soil brot in to finish to ditch. This can be done next year. This fall will see, I hope, the terrace completed. Some muck will have to be put on fill to ensure a catch of grass seed. We were able to get the 40 loads without cost when a ditch was being repaired.

What I would like to know, now, is how much of a grant can we
look for this year.

You will recall, I think, that I said I would do the work on garage if it were framed. I can put siding and roof on after Mr. Torrence frames the building. A cement foundation seems to be the better one, a wall of about 8 feet including footing is sufficient. This will cost about $25.00 alone. I would very much like to know just how much money the Dep't will allow this year so that we can get going on the garage. I had thought of having a gravel floor in garage for the present. It had been suggested that a cement slab be put in to serve as floor and as a footing for the walls. I have not asked Mr. Torrence just how much his charge will be for framing the building. Some new timber will have to be bot for plates.

The windows from the Ipperwash building are the property of Mr. Torrence but I thought I would buy sufficient from him. The verandah will extend the full width of the building and just wide enough to make use of the cement entrance to door. A wider one would be better but it would entail much more expense. This would be glassed in and screened in. The ship-lap could be used for siding in the expectation that insul-brick be put on later to conform to the general type of buildings.

These are the plans for this year. More to come re grounds next year.

Sincerely yours,

Fred J. Dodson.
Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources,
OTTAWA, Ontario.

Enclosed please find voucher #418 for $86.49 in favour of Tracy E. Torrance, 853 E. Wellington Street, Sarnia, Ontario, being in payment for repair work performed at St. Clair Indian Day School.

The junior classroom in St. Clair School is located in the basement. It was opened on September 6th under a new teacher, Mrs. Omond. Blackboards in this room were destroyed in the fire and we had to have new ones installed on the concrete wall. We had blackboard material on hand, but other materials such as lumber for the frame and bolts, etc. were supplied by Mr. Torrance at a cost of $14.95. His labour in installing twenty-eight feet of blackboard in the junior room of this school amounted to $40.00 which is a reasonable amount for the work involved.

The coal bin at the school had to have a partition to separate the stoker coal from the egg size anthracite. The stoker coal is used in the furnace in the school and
the egg size anthracite is for the teacher's residence. An extra doorway had to be cut in as indicated on the account. The total cost of the materials and labour for alterations and partition in the coal bin amounted to $31.54.

The above-mentioned work was very necessary and I recommend that the account be paid. Mr. Torrance, the man who did the work, was the contractor who rebuilt the present school and converted it from a military building into four classrooms.

I wish to refer to Purchase Order #49354 dated October 13th, 1949 covering the purchase of 12 kindergarten chairs for use in the St. Clair Indian Day School. The purchase order was in favour of Henderson Furniture Company, St. Lambert, Quebec.

These kindergarten chairs have been received. However, the junior teacher and Principal have informed me that desks rather than kindergarten chairs were required. No requisition for kindergarten chairs was submitted through this office and I am rather mystified as to how they came to be ordered. Mrs. Omond, the junior teacher, states that she can use the chairs and that they will be more suitable than the small kindergarten chairs which are already on hand. Many of the pupils in Grade 1 who will be using these chairs are older and bigger than ordinary Grade 1 pupils. In view of the fact that the chairs have already been shipped, I suggest that we keep them for use in the St. Clair School.
The 18 large size chair desks ordered by the Principal on requisition dated October 15th, 1949 are still required. When Mr. A. J. Doucet visited Walpole Island recently the desk situation at St. Clair School was discussed and he suggested that I submit a requisition outlining our requirements.

I have instructed the teachers at St. Clair School to leave the kindergarten chairs in the packing cases in the event that you wish them returned. It would be rather expensive to pay shipping charges if they were to be returned and after giving the matter careful consideration we believe that the chairs can be put to good use in the St. Clair School. Kindly advise at an early date as to your wishes with regard to keeping or returning the kindergarten chairs and also advise if you intend to approve of the purchase of an additional 18 large size chair desks as per requisition dated October 15th.

Ottawa, Sept. 15, 1921.

Memorandum.

Mr. McLean:

The school teachers on the Rama reserve took me in to see their living quarters at the Rama school. The living-room and two bed-rooms have not been painted or decorated since the school was built and they are very dirty and badly in need of fresh paint and calcimine. I would suggest that the floors have a coat of jap-a-lac. The windows have no curtains and I believe that it would only be right to furnish them. The floors are bare without any carpets of any kind and I would suggest buying two small floor mats for the rooms.

They also require:

- 10 Geographies for classes 3 and 4.
- 10 Arithmetics
- 10 Histories
- 1 large bottle of ink,
- 1 large box of crayons.

R.H. Abraham

also 8 yds curtain
x 1 Mat for living Room
OTTAWA, Sept. 16th, 1921.

Sir,

Mr. R. H. Abraham, Agricultural Representative of this Department, who recently visited the Rama Reserve, states that the teachers' quarters have not been painted or decorated since the school was built, and that they are very dirty and badly in need of fresh paint and kalsomine. He also recommends that the floors receive a coat of Jap-a-lac, and that window curtains be supplied. He also recommends that 2 small floor mats for the bedrooms and a floor covering for the living room be supplied.

I have to request that you will be good enough to furnish a report regarding the painting and kalsomining which you would recommend should be done. It is considered that if the woodwork was given one coat of paint and the walls and ceiling kalsomined that this would be sufficient. You should also furnish an estimate of the cost of supplying 2 small floor mats for the bedrooms and oilcloth or congoleum for the living room, and also the cost of the curtains required for the windows.

I will be pleased if you will give this matter your prompt attention.

Mr. Abraham also recommended that a number of school books be furnished and these are being ordered from the Government Stationery Office here.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Acting Asst. Deputy & Secretary.

CHATHAM, ONT.
Nov. 3, 1922.

Dear Sir:

While at the Rama Reserve recently, Miss Bowman drew my attention to the fact that they have nothing but straight backed chairs in their living quarters and they would like very much being provided with a couple of rocking chairs. They also require tan window blinds the windows being without them at the present time.

I beg to recommend that the above purchase be authorized. I think the least that we could do would be to provide an easy chair for the teachers.

They have also a bill for $4 for installation of a light in the hall of the school. They state that when they come in at night they have to walk through the dark hall to turn on the light in their living quarters. They also state that when there is an entertainment at the school that this light is very necessary. They paid for the installation of this light, $4, and I think that it should be refunded to them as it is a permanent fixture in the school and was quite necessary.

Yours truly,

J.D. McLean, Secy.,
Dept. of Ind. Aff.,

In reply to your questions, I may say that the residence is attached to the classrooms and accommodates both senior and junior teachers. It is furnished with the necessary furniture and equipment, with the exception of linens, etc. The building is heated by a furnace in the basement. There is a supplementary unit in the senior room and a cook stove in the kitchen. Fuel is supplied by the Department and a janitor employed.
Sir:

I have your letter of the 19th instant, with reference to the conditions of the engagement of Mrs. Stickle, newly appointed senior teacher at the Rama Indian Day School. It is true that the Department is particularly interested in household science, but I am not prepared to authorize the supplying of a sewing machine at the present time. Later, after the work is well under way, if this equipment appears to be urgently needed, you may again bring the matter to the attention of the Department.

There is no change of policy in connection with what should be supplied to the teachers at this school, but I wish to make Mrs. Stickle feel as comfortable as possible. In my offer to her, I stated that the necessary furniture and equipment, with the exception of linens, etc., was provided. I mentioned that fuel was supplied by the Department and a janitor employed. I consider that the teachers should continue to pay the electric light charges and supply the smallware, etc., necessary.

With reference to the time table and course of studies to be followed, you may inform Mrs. Stickle that the Department wishes her to be guided by the curriculum prescribed by the Ontario Department of Education. She should give the practical work particular emphasis and should endeavour to correlate classroom exercises with the activities of the children's homes and environment. You might refer Mrs. Stickle to the advice and instructions printed on the covers of the classroom register.

Your obedient servant,

A. S. Anderson, Esq.,
Indian Agent,

Whereas the school teacher's residence has been a long felt want on this Reserve and believing that the efficiency of the teacher's work would be enhanced in the community by the erection of a teacher's residence on the Reserve. Regarding my telephone conversation on Friday, July 18th with Col. Neary I beg to report further in connection with converting the old St. Clair School into a teacherage.

I requested the Shaw Construction Company of Sarnia to explore the possibilities and give me a rough estimate of the cost.

This single classroom is $24'3"$ x $31'9"$. It is on a good cement foundation and the building is red brick. It has a good roof and good hardwood floor. Of course the floor would have to be sanded to make it suitable for a teacherage.

The present classroom could be partitioned to allow for the following rooms:

- 2 bedrooms each $9' x 11'$
- 1 front room $11' x 13'$
- 1 dining room $13' x 16'$
- 1 kitchen $13' x 16'$
- 1 bathroom $9'11" x 5'9\frac{1}{2}"

Water pressure system is available by tapping the existing line now serving the new St. Clair School. The building could be wired for electricity as hydro is also available. This building could be heated by an oil heater. The large bell and turret presently on the roof could be removed.

Estimated cost of conversion which would include everything except oil heater, septic tank, wiring and bathroom fixtures would be $1500.00. The total cost would probably be $2500.00 and if this amount were spent I think we would have a comfortable residence large enough to accommodate two teachers.

Shaw Construction Company are reasonably certain that they could procure the necessary materials as and when required and estimate that the entire conversion could be completed in three weeks. I think they are somewhat optimistic re the time element. Under existing conditions I think it might take possibly six weeks. The Shaw Construction Company could commence alterations almost at once.

Your further comments with regard to advisability of spending $2500.00 or perhaps $3000.00 in reconverting this building into a teacherage will be awaited.

Indian Agent.

I wish to refer to telegram of August 13th, 1947 from Colonel Neary authorizing an expenditure not to exceed $3100.00 for conversion of the old St. Clair School into a teacher's residence.

The sum of $800.00 was forwarded to pay for labour out of which only $53.00 was spent (receipt #34257). The balance of $747.00 has already been returned to the Chief Treasury Officer under cover of Receiver General returns for period ending November 30th, 1947. The above-mentioned $53.00 was paid to an Indian bricklayer for building a new chimney. Shaw Construction Company paid all other accounts for materials and labour as the job progressed.

First of all you will note that the total claimed by the company is $6800.54 which is more than double their estimated cost of $3100.00.

The mere fact that this company would not take a contract for this job (see my letter with enclosure from Shaw Construction Company dated July 30th) leads one to suspect that they intended to make a killing on the cost plus 15% basis, the same as they did on the new St. Clair School which cost $2000.00 rather than $24000.00, the original estimate.

Close examination of the various accounts attached herewith reveals that the company is endeavouring to collect for a great amount of materials which were definitely not used on our building. This fact is quite obvious even to a layman as in this particular building all materials which were used are more or less in plain view and easily discernible. I am quite certain that much of the material for which we are being charged was used by the company on other jobs.

When the St. Clair School was being built I heard the Superintendent of the company remark that the high cost of same was of
secondary importance as the Government has lots of money and could well afford to pay. I believe they proceeded on this basis when doing the new St. Clair School and continued the same policy when doing the conversion work on the St. Clair teachers' residence. On a cost plus basis it was definitely to the contractor's advantage to prolong the job so as to collect more fee on the time of the men employed and also to charge us for time of men who never worked the number of hours claimed. While the renovating of the residence was in progress I tried to check closely on the cost so as not to exceed the amount allotted and the last time just a week or two before completion their Superintendent told me the total cost was not likely to exceed $4000.00. It is, in my opinion, strange that the total cost jumped from $4000.00 to $6800.00 in so short a time.

At the present time Shaw is apparently in a law suit with the City of Sarnia. He is trying to collect $225.00 for a job which the city engineer claims would be amply paid for at $125.00. This, in itself, shows how exorbitant Shaw's charges are.

An example of overcharging on the new school and residence jobs is quite evident in the case of the foreman, E. Angeliski, who, you will note, was paid a weekly wage of $65.00 during the time these jobs were in progress. I can assure you that on the many occasions that I made trips to note the advancement of the jobs the carpenters repeatedly told me when I inquired for the foreman that he was doing another job for Imperial Oil. They said he usually dropped in for a few minutes between 9:00 and 10:00 A.M. and sometimes before closing time in the afternoon and I might see him then if I could wait. Even then, after waiting around he often times did not appear. In view of this example I am extremely skeptical of time spent on the job by all men on Shaw's paylists.

The company gave the heating and plumbing as a sub-contract to Spiers' Sheet Metal and you will note that Spiers' total bill for plumbing was $526.81 but this did not include two fixtures, i.e., kitchen sink ($35.20) and bathroom basin ($37.50) as the company obtained these themselves direct from Ace Plumbing Company. The total cost of plumbing was $619.51 whereas the plumbing estimate given us by Shaw was $515.00. I consider Spiers' account fairly reasonable although $14.30 should be deducted from Shaw's cheque as he paid them for a shower which was not ordered nor installed. Shaw can then recover the $14.30 from Spiers as he should not have paid them for a shower in the first place.
On or about October 21st when practically all of the work had been completed the Superintendent of Shaw Construction Company at my request sent their bulldozer to the site to level off the clay fill and gravel which they had placed in mounds around the new St. Clair School and residence. The foreman who had been in charge of the renovating of the residence was not present when the bulldozer arrived. However the driver of the bulldozer commenced levelling and ran into the septic tank serving the residence. This powerful machine crushed the septic tank and outlet tile like a leaf and loosened all the plumbing pipes attached thereto. Shaw instructed Spiers Sheet Metal to install another septic tank and repair the twisted and broken pipes. The expenses re this as per Spiers' invoice dated October 22nd were $62.44. In addition a number of Shaw's workmen were sent to dig up the crushed tank, pump water and replace broken tile. The labour for Shaw's men re this connection amounted to $315.50 (see week of October 20th to 25th). Charging us for this utter negligence on their part is ridiculous as their foreman should have been present to point out the location of the septic tank to the operator of the bulldozer.

The total expenses resulting from Shaw's error amount to $379.94 plus his fee of 15% or $457.65 which we should certainly not pay.

The only drainage that was performed to my knowledge was in laying a tile drain from the residence to the road ditch to serve as an outlet for the septic tank. This is seventy-five feet and as tile used were one foot in length it would require seventy-five 4" tile. You will note that Shaw is charging us for seven hundred and eighty-five tile as per accounts from James Builders dated September 26th and September 29th at a cost of $39.68 instead of the actual cost of seventy-five tile used on this job at a cost of $3.75. A reduction of $35.93 from Shaw should be made re the above.

With regard to Spiers sub-contract for heating I would refer you to the original estimate of $950.00. When this estimate was prepared everyone assumed that a completely new heating unit would have to be installed. Later it was decided that the old coal furnace previously used in the St. Clair School would suffice rather than buy a new unit. The total expenditure for heating apparatus with the exception of the erection of the chimney was $355.91 and by using the old furnace a considerable saving over the original estimate was effected.

The estimate of $204.42 for wiring was exceeded as this figure covered a two wire service whereas I instructed Chambers Electric to install a three wire circuit. Light fixtures throughout the residence
costing $24.25 were not included in the original estimate and if they had been the original estimate would have been $228.67. In my opinion the work performed by Chambers Electric was quite satisfactory and his charges of $399.89 are justified as he also performed extra work in connection with installing a circuit for the forced draft heating system.

The painting would not have been required immediately and was omitted in the original estimate but gyproc partitions and ceiling were substituted for lath and plaster thus making painting essential. The painting price included the sanding of floors at a total cost of $693.66—a sum which was agreed upon between the painter and myself after much dispute since the bill the painter, Stanley Angeliski, first submitted was $900.00. This painting and sanding was also done on an hourly basis and when I discovered the ridiculous bill the painter was running up I dismissed him and all his helpers before the job was finished, and my wife and I finished the painting and floors ourselves. It was obvious that the painter, Stanley Angeliski, brother of Shaw's foreman, Edward Angeliski, was copying Shaw's tactics in prolonging the job and running up a bill on the hourly basis. Shaw paid Stanley Angeliski the sum of $693.66 which I eventually authorized but this painter is drunk most of the time and we cannot locate him to sign a receipt although Shaw apparently has the cancelled cheque as proof of payment.

A total of $454.00 is being charged by Shaw for clay fill and gravel. About 75% of this clay and gravel was for the new St. Clair School and the balance was for the residence. When Mr. P. Fhe'an visited Sarnia Agency last August we discussed the placing of cinders or crushed stone around the school. The Shaw Construction Company later convinced me that a quantity of clay fill and pit run gravel would be necessary to fill in huge mud holes which had resulted from trucks, etc., bringing materials on wet days when the school and residence were being built in the Fall of 1946 and Spring and Fall of 1947. I authorized a reasonable amount of clay and gravel to level the grounds and cover septic tanks and drains so they would not freeze but I had no idea that the cost had mounted to $454.00. I was misled by the company in the benefit to be derived from the clay fill and gravel as it has resulted in a muddy sticky mess around the school yard and residence. It may, however, pack down and provide a fairly good base by next year. I believe the company is trying to charge us for much more fill and gravel than was actually supplied. I consider it fair if they were to be allowed $200.00 instead of $454.00. This $454.00 is included in the company's claim against the residence whereas most of it should be a separate charge against the St. Clair School as pointed out to Colonel Neary when he visited Sarnia Agency last October.
The company has submitted a separate claim of $391.64 for laying sidewalk and I am enclosing his account under cover of voucher #577 in this connection. The sidewalk runs from the road to the new school where it joins and leads from there to the front steps of the residence. The cement steps in front of the residence are included in the sidewalk account. The contractor gave me a verbal estimate of $225.00 for this sidewalk which did not include the residence steps. The fact that the residence steps were also built at the same time increased the cost of the sidewalk but not to the extent of $166.64. I think $300.00 would be a fair amount to allow rather than $391.64.

When the conversion work was actually commenced a few defects not previously taken into consideration were discovered. For instance window sash, frames, etc., were quite rotten and completely new ones with glass had to be purchased for all but one window. The old brick chimney could not be used with the new heating unit and a new one had to be built. The large bell and wooden tower on the residence had to be dismantled and the shingle roof patched where the turret had been attached. The wiring was changed from a two to a three wire service. Linoleum for kitchen and bathroom floors at a cost of $14.03 were necessary as well as blinds at $5.10. These were not figured in the original estimate but none of them increased the cost to any great degree and the extra expenditures were more than offset by utilizing the old furnace rather than purchasing a new one as originally planned.

We have a compact, comfortable and modern residence here now although it is not in any sense elaborate as Shaw's account would lead one to believe. It consists of two bedrooms, living-room, dining-room, kitchen, bath and furnace room all on one floor and will provide suitable sleeping and living quarters for two or possibly three single teachers if all were of the same sex. It is also large enough to accommodate a married teacher and his or her family if desired. We moved into this residence on October 4th as authorized in Departmental letter 29-1-1 of September 1st, 1947.

On an attached sheet I have listed the various items which were not used on the job and I have indicated reductions which I consider should be made in Shaw's claim. However, before Shaw is paid I think it would be wise to have a Departmental building engineer inspect the teachers' residence to confirm my statements re the contractor's exorbitant charges and claims for time and materials which were never spent or used on this building.
I strongly recommend that this claim of Shaw Construction for $6800.54 under voucher #578 be paid at and that the amount for laying sidewalk under voucher #577 be paid at $300.00. If such action is taken the original estimate to convert the old school into a residence for two teachers will not have been exceeded to any great extent.

I also wish to point out that one of the workmen purchased the old window frames at a cost of seventy-five cents each or a total of $6.00. The foreman, E. Angeliski, said he would deduct this from the time of the workman but the bookkeeper of Shaw's on being questioned regarding same admitted that no deduction had been made to his knowledge. Some small tools valued at $12.85, being two cold chisels and one lantern, were transferred from the new school job to the teachers' residence job. The auditor indicated that we should be allowed a credit of 50% of the cost. On the enclosed account no credit of this nature has been allowed.

M. W. McCracken

I have noted on the plan lent me by the Trust Branch the number of the buildings available to the Indian Affairs. They are Nos. 11, 12, 13, 14, 41, 44, 45 and 46. No. 11 is a salvage shed, well constructed on a cement floor, it is 20' x 60'. Nos. 12, 13 and 14 are H. Huts. No. 12 is intact but Nos. 13 and 14 have been partly dismantled.

No. 41 is the Dental Clinic and would be very practical as classrooms. It is 24' x 70'.

The problem is to find out if these buildings can economically be transported. If so, one might be set on the present foundation of the burnt school.

A second plan would be to rebuild the school from material available from the camp. Considerable material of the school is usable in its present shape. The beams appear sound as well as the joists, the sub floor and some walls.

I would suggest that immediate steps be taken to investigate the cost of transporting these buildings should it prove to be feasible.

With reference to the furnishings for the living quarters at the St. Clair School, the Purchasing Branch is being requested to order what we consider necessary.

I wish to acknowledge receipt of your letter 29-1-8 of October 18th, 1948 in which you request information regarding an electric stove to be supplied for use in the St. Clair teacher's residence.

Electric stoves are very difficult to obtain. Some of the stores in this city did not have any for sale. Others had some stoves but salesmen pointed out that they had to be purchased almost immediately or else some other person buys them. For this reason it is impossible for me to state the name and address of any firm who would be in a position to supply a stove. I think authority should be given to purchase one locally wherever it may be found in stock.

A four burner electric stove of a reliable make would cost approximately $220.00. Two burner stoves such as the Amca, Grahamette and Sunshine range in price from $84.95 to $103.50. I think a two burner stove such as the Sunshine costing approximately $103.50 would be suitable. The present teacher of the school would be satisfied with a stove of this type and I recommend that authority be granted to purchase it or one of a similar nature.

M. W. McCracken,
Superintendent, Sarnia Indian Agency.

We are told there were a number of 4 burner stoves on the floor at Eaton's in Toronto. There was a 4 br. at $229 in London and a 2 br. at $129. These were sent in. The 4 br. would be better for a home. The 2 br. would be better than a rangette. We would like to have a stove of some kind before Christmas.

The bed-room furniture and kitchen table and chairs are at Station today. Cooking utensils have also arrived.

If the Department feels that the 4 br. is too expensive we hope the 2 br. will soon be along. We appreciate the fact that there is a lot of money being spent on this project but think that good material will last longer in the long run.

I am hoping that there will be enough lumber left over for a garage. If the Dept. would give the material I would be glad to arrange to have the work done. I could do most of it myself. If the frame work was put up I would do the rest myself.

I realize much money is being spent so I shall be glad to lessen amount by doing as much work as I can. There will be a great deal of levelling to be done and much fill to be brought in before we can attempt to get any grass around house or school. Over a period of years much can be accomplished, tho.

I hope you will be able to get things moving a little faster re Teacherage.

Sincerely yours,

Fred J. Dodson.
