Sir,

Naturally children with no exceptions resent confinement especially so with boys consequently they don't appreciate being kept in school-room during the best part of the day. They would sooner rebel the authority of the teacher if they dared to than to conform themselves to his rules and regulations. It seems to me it is just simply little less than wasting money in keeping up Indian schools that I have seen. The chief cause of the failure is that Indian children don't attend school regularly as they should, and punctuality is wanting in Indian schools on the part of the children and some times on the part of the teacher. It is very trying and discouraging to good, honest & faithful teachers to see Indian children wasting away their opportunities and privileges. There are also teachers who do not care whether their school is a success or failure as long as their quarterly payments come.

As I take great interest in education of the Indian children I would like to see the Indian Department take some remedial
Steps to ward the failure of the Indian Day Schools. Entering into one of the houses at Sheguiandah Reserve last winter saw five or six boys spending the day there instead of spending their time in the School. "This is the every day occurrence," said a woman that was there. Instead of these boys going to school when the bell rings they come here and remain around here during the school time. There is too much of this sort thing going on among the Indian Day Schools. Teachers cannot prevent it. Parents don't care or don't know any better. It is only the Dept. of Indian Affairs has authority to remedy this defect. I don't wish for a moment that Indian Department should exercise its authority tyrannically to ward the Indians about the schools.

But I believe it is for the advantage of the Indians that their children should attend the schools better or else send their children to Indian Homes or Institutions.

Dear Sir,

I feel I must add a few words to my report which please find enclosed. I am asked to deal with the work on the Reserve beside that of the Schoolroom. I have only been here since April 1, 1914 and as I can find no place to board on the Reserve, must have to walk 1½ miles to a farm. I see very little of the Indians. I have always found the Indian men or women friendly & obliging in manners. Nearly all speak English well, and one especially is well educated & very intelligent. I have heard him translate promptly & excellently the Sermon of the Bishop of Algoma on his last visit to this part, it was at Sheguiandah last summer. The time he has been teacher at Silver Water, on this island. He now lives here.

The men, many of them, work at loading canoes at Little Current, the women find work there too, washing, cooking, housework which I am told they do well.

If there were a garden attached to the School the teacher could easily interest the children in vegetable growing, and poultry keeping. The land I am told is good soil, and the farming very productive. The stumps of the old burnt bush of 40 years ago are still standing in all their ugliness on the land in front of the School, which lies low, is swampy, and in summer a paradise for mosquitoes.
When I first came here, I boarded with
the old Squaw Katherine Maygrath, a sensible
old woman, with much knowledge of the world,
good manners and excellent English. She had
great good influence on the Reserve, and was
famous all around for good nursing and
other work. She is dead now, and the difference
is perceptible in her house.

My dear Mr. Lewis,

It is a standing rule which in my Episcopate of nearly 20 years I have not known to be ignored that the authorities of the Church are allowed to nominate or recommend teachers for our Indian Day Schools. When I learned that you had recommended someone else than Mr. Roberts and that he notwithstanding my recommendation had been rejected I must confess I was very much surprised.

I immediately wrote to the Department at Ottawa (not of course giving any names) to ascertain whether the traditional rule had been altered. I am assured by the Deputy Superintendent General that it has not.

I do not know Miss Bertha Wedgefield so far as I can remember. I have not heard her name before. You say she attends the Anglican Church; but you do not say whether she is a communicant or even a member of that communion.

Many people attend our services who know very little about our principles & practices. I say nothing whatever against Miss Bertha Wedgefield nor do I question the excellence of her general qualifications. I know nothing about her. Dear Mr. Dean,

Mr. Lewis, the Indian Agent at Manitowaning, puts me in a very awkward position indeed by recommending someone I never heard of, and antagonizing my nominee for the Sucker Creek School.

I nominated Mr. Malcolm Roberts and so far as I know, no valid objection has been raised against him. The reasons Mr. Lewis gave him for the refusal of his application were simply that he ought to enlist or to engage in manual labour. Now setting aside the improbability of this mode of escape, there was absolutely no ground for it. Mr. Roberts had offered himself for military service more than once that been refused; and his strength is not equal to hard manual labour. There was no complaint made as to the adequacy of his technical qualifications.

Under the circumstances, therefore, I do not see any way to withdraw my recommendation of Mr. Roberts in favour of the young lady named who is a total stranger to me and whom not a member your communion.

I am faithfully yours,

George Wilson

Sir:

With reference to Official Letter No. 19-4-I of the 17th of September last, in regard to the Department communicating with His Grace the Archbishop of Algoma to nominate a qualified teacher to succeed Miss Bertha Wedgerfield as teacher at the Sucker Creek Indian School, I have the honor to report that I have had a communication from His Grace the Archbishop stating that at the moment of writing the only available person in view was Miss Schultz to succeed Miss Wedgerfield and asked me to let him know whether I am averse to her appointment.

I have informed His Grace the Archbishop that as Miss Schultz had taught at Sucker Creek previous to the appointment of Miss Wedgerfield and she did not prove satisfactory to some of the Indians, and as there are qualified teachers who have experience teaching in the district public schools that are willing to accept the position at Sucker Creek, therefore, I did not approve of the nomination of Miss Schultz.

The Archbishop is further informed that there is a Miss Janet McDonald of this village who is willing to accept the position. She is twenty years of age and has experience teaching on some of the district public schools. She has not yet become a member of any church but is willing to teach the principals of the Anglican Church in the Sucker Creek School if instructed by the Missionary in charge of the band.

I might say that the Sucker Creek School is now one of the best conducted Indian school in the district and it is my wish to secure the services of a qualified teacher to succeed Miss Wedgerfield in order that its success may continue.

Miss McDonald will accept the position at a salary at the rate of $500.00 per annum and the bonus which is being allowed to teachers in Indian school, and she is ready to take charge at any time.

I would most respectfully recommend that Miss McDonald be appointed as successor to Miss Wedgerfield, as I have every reason to believe that she is a competent teacher.

Madam,

I am directed to acknowledge the receipt of your letters of the 20th and 21st instant with reference to the amount of salary you received for the period you taught the Sucker Creek Indian Day School during the month of September.

In connection with this matter I beg to say that each school year begins upon the re-opening of the schools after the summer holidays, on or about the first of September, and terminates at the close of the following June. You first began duties at this school on September 1st, 1916, and completed four school years on June 30th, 1920, and you received four years salary in full. At the beginning of last September you started another year, teaching during the month of September, and, as you had given notice of your intention to resign, salary could only be paid for the actual number of days you taught, payment being made for twenty-one days and the amount paid $55.13. A return has since been received for the nine days you taught during the present month and a cheque for $23.62 is being sent. The bonus was also paid you for the month of September and you have thus received the full amount due you for your services.

Payment of salary is based on the number of teaching days in the year; all Indian schools are required to be kept open for not less than two hundred days in each year, in order that the full yearly salary can be paid. A copy of the Indian Day School Regulations is enclosed herewith, which will show the method adopted in the payment of teachers salaries.

If you continue as teacher until the 30th of June next, teaching the required number of days, you will be entitled to your full yearly salary. In this connection, however, I beg to say that His Grace the Archbishop of Algoma, under whose auspices the school is conducted, has been endeavouring to obtain a successor and, before the Department could approve of your remaining as teacher, it would be necessary for you to communicate with His Grace and obtain his consent. Your services have been satisfactory and your work in connection with the school fair is appreciated, but the Department cannot pay any salary in excess of the actual days taught.

Your obedient servant,

A. S. Williams

Sir:

I have the honour to report that I visited Sucker Creek Indian School on the 27th ultimo, and found it closed on account of all the pupils suffering from an epidemic of influenza and not any could attend. The teacher opened school but not any of the pupils came and on visiting the different homes he found that the children were all ill and a great number of the parents were not able to look after their live stock. In the houses where they are all ill the teacher is looking after them, such as feeding their live stock and carrying in firewood, and as soon as the pupils recover to warrant the re-opening of the school he will resume his duties in the class-room.

I might say for the information of the Department that an epidemic of influenza has visited all the reserves in this agency and in many of the homes the whole family have been ill at the same time, but very few deaths have occurred from the disease, although some have been very ill.

Dear Mr. Balfour,

I have just returned from Sucker Creek Indian Mission where I administered Holy Communion to 11 members. Things are settling down nicely & the people are behaving well.

I understand that Mr. Lewis, the Indian Agent, was at Sucker Creek last Friday again urged the Indians to hold a meeting for the purpose of getting the school closed.

It's hard to understand why the Agent should be persistently trying to get this school closed. He induced the Indians a short time ago, to call a meeting for the same purpose & the closing of the school was turned down. The Indians have stated clearly again again that they wish the school kept open & still the agent is urging keeping at them to have it closed. When he knows perfectly well that the Indians do not wish it closed. He must have reasons known only to himself for doing this.
There are six children attending the school who have Indian rights & five who have not, owing to children be illegitimate.

There is a total of eleven on the roll & several coming along (5 or 6) children who have Indian rights.

Regarding the others, these must have schooling also, & the Dept. of Indian Affairs is responsible to a certain degree for these children. What is to be done unless they are allowed to attend the school?

If the school is closed where will the 11 children now attending go to school? There is no school within reasonable distance. Most of them absolutely refuse to let their children go away from home; it means no schooling for these 11 children if the school is closed.

We can only influence these people for good by keeping both the Church & the school going. Things are just settling down nicely. If the school is closed it will be fatal to the work.

I will be glad if you would forward a copy of this letter to the Indian Dept. (to Mr. C. Scott Esq.) that he may
learn the true facts of the case.

The Inspector has continually urged a new school at Sucker Creek, but he told me himself that the agent had worked so persistently against him that he had given up trying.

If the Dept. of Indian Affairs do not build a new school, they should, at least, put a new floor & repaint the old building, especially inside.

I had a talk with His Lordship, the Bishop, on this matter & he is perfectly in accord with me. He has visited the mission & learned the full facts.

As regards accepting these children into Shingwauk Home, first the parents are against doing so & some absolutely refuse. Secondly, it would be folly to accept any of them into the home at the present time for more reasons than one.

I hope I have made the matter clear & I think the Agent should be told to let this matter alone.

I remain, Dear Mr. Balfour,

Yours sincerely,
C. Weeks.

MEMO FOR FILE:

On the 28th ultimo, I visited the Sucker Creek Indian Day School and found about the most miserable excuse for a school that it has been my fortune to visit. The building is terrible - holes in the floor, etc., and the present teacher, Miss Rosalind Weeks, did not show any enthusiasm. There were four or five children there and one boy had his cap on. Two others were playing marbles in the corner. I was afraid to ask if it was supposed to be recess, because the door was shut and all were in the school. It was a bright, sunny day.

I selected a new site and, as soon as funds are available, the Department will have to rebuild. In the meantime, there is no reason why some effort should not be made with the present equipment, and the first step will be to secure a new teacher.

Mr. Indian Agent Lewis is quite satisfied that the attendance would improve considerably if a good teacher were appointed. The Chief of the Band is supposed to be the truant officer, but he is evidently useless for this purpose. It may be necessary to use the services of the police from time to time.

Venerable Sir:

I have to inform you that the Superintendent of Indian Education recently visited the Sucker Creek Indian Day School and that he believes there should be a change of teacher if any progress is to be made. At the present time, three factors militate against a successful school. The building is old and dilapidated and will have to be replaced as soon as funds can be provided for the purpose. Second, the attendance is poor and should show a considerable increase. Third, the teacher is not qualified and does not seem to have the faculty of making the instruction bright and attractive. Mr. Indian Agent Lewis, who knows the Indians of this reserve, believes that a qualified teacher, using suitable methods, would secure a worthwhile attendance without having recourse to the services of the police.

Dear Sir:

I would invite reference to your letters No. 19-4-1 of June 24th, 1931 to the Ven. C.W. Balfour, and dated July 7th, 1931 to myself regarding the Sucker Creek Indian day school.

In these letters you state, what is undoubtedly a fact, that the building is old and dilapidated and will have to be replaced at a very early date. You state, however, that the Department will not consider the building of a new school unless there is the assurance of a worthwhile attendance. You therefore asked me to make a special effort to obtain a properly qualified teacher, and with your approval Mr. George Dill started work on September 1st last.

I do not know if you have received any reports of Mr. Dill's work, but those which I have received are so satisfactory that I would wish to call your special attention to them. There is at present a registration of fourteen pupils, and the average attendance for the last quarter was 12.6. This compares very favourably with the average attendance of six for the corresponding quarter of last year. There are not only pupils in grades one, two and three, but also two pupils in the entrance class and one in the first form of high school. Music lessons have been started with four of the pupils. In the recent school fair the pupils did extraordinarily well, winning forty-one prizes, I am told, at the Little Current Fair, together with five in athletics. They also won prizes in the Manitoulin Fair at Gore Bay. Considering the shortness of time during which Mr. Dill has been in charge I think that this augurs well for the future.

I would like to urge upon the Department, however, that it will be quite impossible for me to retain the services of so good a teacher as Mr. Dill unless there is some hope that very soon the school building will be replaced by something a little more suitable for the purpose. It does not seem fair that the Indians at Sucker Creek should have to put up with a building so distinctly inferior to most of the Indian schools, and it is a great drawback that there is no teacher's house on the reserve. Mr. Dill has organized a Sunday School class which is beginning to do a good work for the moral and spiritual uplift of both pupils and parents, but it is difficult to carry on work of this sort when he has to live at some distance from his work. If he were able to live on the Reserve he could exercise a splendid influence over the older boys and girls who have at present no supervision over their leisure hours. The school is in such a state that it is really not worthwhile considering the
many major repairs which are urgently necessary, for it seems a waste of money to spend anything upon so dilapidated a building.

I trust that the Department will consider this a matter demanding urgent attention, and that they will give me what support they can in retaining the services of so enthusiastic and capable a teacher as Mr. Dill.

Believe me,

Yours sincerely,

Dear Sirs:

This is my report for the Indian Anglican School on Sucker Creek Reserve for the past year.

We people on this Reserve are not satisfied with the management of our School under Mr. Dill.

The School was two weeks late in starting in September, when we engaged Miss Turnbull, who taught a month until Mr. Dill came. He taught until December 14th, when he closed the school until January 9th. He took sick the 9th February, and the School was closed until February 27th, when we engaged Miss Turnbull. She taught, and carried the work successfully until June 19th, when Mr. Dill came back to take the school over for the last two weeks. At this time Miss Turnbull was in the midst of her June examinations, and also the School Fair Exhibits, in writing, drawing etc. The Indian Agent instructed her, to pass over the keys to Mr. Dill, which was a very big disappointment to the children and the parents. Miss Turnbull is well liked by the children, and held at a very high esteem by everyone on the Reserve. Moreover the children were so disappointed about their annual Pic-nic, which the teacher had made preparations for, and was not celebrated at all.

The children refused to attend school after he came back, and it is certain that the attendance will be none, if Mr. Dill comes back in September.

Yours respectfully,

Chief: Chas Abotossaway

Dear Mr. Hoey:

Yesterday I received a letter from Dr. Kingston, Bishop of Algoma, and he suggested that I write to you.

As the Bishop will have told you, I am to teach school at Sucker Creek, on Manitoulin Island. I shall be there sometime on Tuesday, September 28th, and the school will be opening either September 29th or 30th.

You will no doubt know from Dr. Kingston, that I have four years' High School, but that I did not complete my Junior Matriculation. I have English Literature, Composition, French Authors, French Grammar, Physics, Canadian History, and Upper School Literature and Composition.

When I left High School, I took a business course at the Sudbury Business College, and after eight months there, I secured a position
as stenographer at Palm Dairies Limited, in Sudbury. I was with them fifteen months, then worked for the International Nickel Company of Canada, Limited, at Copper Cliff, in the Pay Office. I was there almost ten months, leaving in June of this year. I did not work during July and August, and this month I have been temporarily employed in the Treasurer's Department at the City Hall in Sudbury.

I have been a Girl Guide for ten years, and since January, 1942, I have been Captain of 4th Sudbury (One) Company. My guiding experience will, I am sure, stand me in good stead at the Sucker Creek School, as I have been a Guider for the last five years.

I have also taught a Sunday school class for three and one-half years.

I am twenty-one years of age.

Thank you very much for approving my appointment.

Yours sincerely,

(Miss) Marion Rothery.

The results of unqualified teachers are reflected, particularly at Sucker Creek and Buswah Schools, both in progress and attendance. I would recommend qualified teachers be secured for these schools next term, if at all possible.

The present minimum salary in provincial schools is making it increasingly difficult to secure qualified teachers for Indian Schools, and I am of the opinion it will be necessary to make some adjustment in this respect if we are to keep our schools operating. Dear Sir:

From October, 1943 until June, 1945, I taught at Sucker Creek Indian Day School, near Little Current, Ontario.

In the last week of May, 1944, one of the pupils, Terry Corbiere, age 9 (1944) was very disobedient, and in the course of events, when I was trying to restore order and make him return to his desk, he hit me with his fist, catching me in the right breast. I expelled the child, but taught him the next year. He was bad, as usual, but did not cause quite so much uproar as before.
Almost immediately, I noticed a small lump forming where Jerry had hit me. During the Christmas vacation, 1944, my doctor advised that it be left for some time, unless it increased in size.

In September, 1945, I returned to high school, after a 5-year absence, to secure normal school entrance. I then noticed an increase in the size of the lump on my breast, and in April, was advised to have it removed as soon as possible.

The Departmental examinations finished June 25, and I started hospital here that evening; On June 27, my doctor removed two tumours.

I feel that some adjustment or compensation should be made by the Indian Affairs Branch, for I certainly was
is no way responsible for the way in which the tumours were caused.

My hospital bill was $28.50, my doctors' bills $62.00, a total of $90.50.

I am at present preparing to attend North Bay Normal School next week, and really would appreciate the return of this money.

If you so desire, I can forward you my receipts.

Kindly let me know what adjustment the Department will make.

Thank you.

Yours truly,

Marion Rothery.

When an employee while on duty suffers an accident requiring medical attention, a form "Employer's Report of Accident" must be completed by the Indian Agent; and a medical form "Surgeon's First Report" also must be completed by the attending physician. These forms are to be completed in quadruplicate, three to be forwarded to this Branch and the fourth copy to be retained by you for your files.

All persons employed by the department in any capacity regardless of the nature or class of their employment, that is whether permanent, temporary, full time, part time, seasonal or casual are covered by the Act, so long as they are paid a direct wage or salary by the Government.

All cases of accident on duty requiring medical attention and/or which are sufficiently serious that a claim for compensation might be involved should be investigated and reported by the Indian Agent with as little delay as possible, as any unnecessary delay may render it difficult to establish the facts required to support the claim and as long delays
may disqualify any claim.

I am returning, therefore, the forms submitted by Miss Rothery. Employer's Report of accident to be completed in the required number of forms and signed by you, also the Surgeon's First Report to be signed by the attending physician, and returned to this Branch for further action.

Dear Mr. Farquhar:

I wonder if you can help me?

I have written to Mr. Johnston at Manitowaning and he forwarded my letter to Ottawa. Then he sent me Workmen's Compensation Board forms, which I filled in and returned. Since then, I have heard no more.

Here is what happened. In May, 1944, near the end of my first year at Sucker Creek, Jerry Corbierrie was unruly one day, and when I tried to manage him, he punched me. The blow caught me in the right breast. I put Jerry out, and he did not return to school until the next September. By the fall, I noticed a small lump, and when I was home at Christmas, my Doctor advised that it be left for a while, but stated that it had certainly been caused by Jerry's fist.

In April of this year, I was again examined, when two tumours were found. I was advised to have them removed immediately. As I was at High School here, I had to wait until the end of June, after the final examinations. I wrote my last examination the afternoon of June 27, and entered hospital that evening. They operated June 27, and removed the two tumours.

I failed the examination which I wrote that last afternoon, and was admitted to North Bay Normal School because my doctor sent a letter stating the cause of my failing it.

I see no reason why I should have to pay the expenses of this operation. I have inquired about it, and had I been in an ordinary white school (where it is hardly like such a thing could happen) I could have claimed my expenses.

Since it was during school hours, and I was doing my duty as the teacher, I feel the Indian Department should be responsible for these expenses:

| Expense       | Amount |
|---------------|--------|
| Hospital      | $28.50 |
| Dr. Orange    | 10.00  |
| Dr. McInnes   | 53.00  |
| Total         | $91.50 |

I cannot see that it is a Compensation case at all, nor can the Normal School teachers. I lost no time at all, either when it happened or later on.
Since I am at Normal School, I really need this money, as I paid these bills out of what I had saved for Normal School.

Can you help me? I will be so grateful if you can.

I would appreciate hearing from you soon.

Thank you

Yours sincerely,

(Signed) Marion Rothery.

If you wish to have receipts, or further particulars, I will certainly let you have them.

Dear Mr. Farquhar:

This will acknowledge your letter of February 5 with enclosure from Miss Marion Rothery, 380 John Street, Sudbury, Ontario, formerly a teacher at the Sucker Creek Indian School.

This matter is receiving the attention of the Indian Affairs Branch.

It appears to be a case for consideration by the Ontario Workmen's Compensation Board under the provisions of the Government Employees' Compensation Act (Dominion).

As you may be aware under the Government Employees' Compensation Act, all Dominion Government employees are covered for compensation for accidents or injuries received in the course of their duty. The Dominion, however, does not maintain a Board and consequently by arrangement the Provincial Boards deal with cases arising under the Dominion Act. The Boards use their own Provincial regulations as to reasons for compensation, rates of compensation and so forth, except that all Dominion employees are covered, regardless of vocation, which is ordinarily restricted under the Provincial Acts. The Provincial Boards either make an award or reject the claim and in the event of an award, the cost is met by the Dominion Government.

As a teacher in an Indian school, Miss Marion Rothery, was eligible for consideration under the procedure outlined above. Unfortunately the matter was not reported to the Department until more than a year after the injury was received and this may complicate the case in view of the time limit under the Provincial Act and regulations.

Through a misunderstanding Miss Rothery completed and signed certain required forms herself, whereas these should have been signed by the Indian Agent and the attending physician.
The Indian Agent at Manitowaning was instructed to straighten this out but so far the forms properly completed have not been received from him. He is again being asked to submit a report and you will be advised as to further developments in the case.

"I will expect a salary of fourteen hundred"

I do not know how to answer that at all. It was a complication that I had not foreseen, nor had the Bishop I think anticipated it. Unfortunately the Bishop is out of town or I would take the whole thing back to him. Is it possible to meet that demand, or should we look for someone else to fall in, in the meantime?

I am deeply concerned by your last paragraph re Spanish River School. I believe that that matter was entirely settled and that Mr. Armstrong had been appointed to the position. I have in my possession a very definite letter from him saying that he will be on the job the first day of school and that we can count on him. Have I slipped somewhere in making the arrangement final and definite? I sent you I believe his completed application form and felt that that would conclude the matter. I am afraid that through my inexperience in these matters I have complicated the situation. Unless you have had word from Mr. Armstrong to the contrary, I am quite certain that he is planning and expecting to teach at Spanish River School and will be in the job on September 7th. If there is anything further that I should do in this matter would you let me know at your earliest convenience?

I am,

Yours faithfully,

James H. Craig

Dear Col. Neary,

Thank you for your wire of August 31st and also for your letter of September 2nd, which reached me today.

Mrs. McLeod has written me agreeing to teach in the Sucker Creek School until December 1st. As I pointed out in a previous letter, she asked for a salary of $1400 per annum. I am confident however that she will be content with the amount of $1320 which you have informed me she is entitled to under the schedule. I have sent on this word to her today and am sure that she will accept the figure offered without any further question. I have told her if she is not content to get in touch with you direct.

Mrs. Surrey has also written to say that she will be free to take over on December 1st and that she has resigned her other position as from that date. She expressed regret that the salary was not as high as she had expected, but intimated that she would accept the position nevertheless. She asked what the annual increment would be. I said that I understood it would be $60 per year. I asked her to write direct to you accepting the position.

I hope you will feel quite free to offer a school in the Chapleau Agency to Mrs. Anderson. We felt that in years to come she might be available for the Sucker Creek School, if ever the present arrangement comes to an end, but that of course was all very indefinite. My correspondence with her convinced me that she would be a very satisfactory teacher and I hope you may have some luck with her.

I trust that the plans made for the Sucker Creek and Spanish River Schools will work out satisfactorily. As the Bishop has now returned from England, such matters as these will now revert into his hands. May I thank you for the many courtesies you have extended to me this summer in our rather lengthy correspondence over these matters?

With every good wish,

I am,

Yours faithfully,

James H. Craig

Sir:

I have to inform you that His Lordship the Bishop of Algoma has nominated the services of Mr. George Frederick Dill for the position as teacher of the Sucker Creek Indian Day School for the coming school year. The Department expects that you will endeavour to have the Indian parents see that their children attend regularly. You should make as frequent visits as you can to this Reserve and see that the attendance is being kept up. If the parents refuse to send their children regularly to school, you may take action under Section 10 of the Indian Act to enforce attendance. Reverend Sir,

I beg to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 4th instant, with reference to the amount paid Miss Turnbull for her services at the Sucker Creek Indian Day School during the quarter ended June 30th, last.

No definite promise was made to Miss Turnbull by the Department regarding the amount she would be allowed for her services. However, when the return was received for the period she taught the school during the quarter ended March 31st, last, it was decided to allow her salary at the rate of $4.50 a day, less 10%. The return showed that she taught the school for 25 days during the March quarter and she was, therefore, allowed $112.50, less 10%, which made the amount due her $101.25.

The return for the June quarter showed that she had taught the Sucker Creek School for 44 days during that quarter and, at the same rate as was allowed her in the March quarter, the amount due was $198.00. Deducting 10% from this amount, the Department forwarded her a cheque for $178.20. There is, therefore, no further balance due her.

For your information, I may add that 10% is deducted from all salaries of teachers of Indian day schools during the current fiscal year.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. Sutherland,
Acting Supt. of Indian Education.

I have the honor to report that this building is in such a condition that it would not pay to expend any money on it. It was never a building of any account and I understand that it originally was built by the Church authorities for the Missionary to keep his horse in and not for wood shed purposes. If anything in this line is to be done I would recommend that a new woodshed 12 feet by 16 feet and 8 feet high in the walls be erected. Sir,

With reference to Official Letter No. 151709-8, dated 5th Instant, and previous correspondence in connection with erecting a new school building on the Sucker Creek Reserve, I have the honor to report that this reserve has been quarantined for measles for some time, and the Chief of the Band is at Sault Ste Marie, Ont., where his wife is undergoing an operation, therefore, it is impossible to have a resolution by the band authorizing the Department to take the necessary amount from the funds at their credit to cover the cost of erecting the new school building. As soon as Dr. P. J. Mc Donald, who has this band under his supervision, sees fit to allow the Indians to hold public meetings, I will take up the question with the band of erecting a new school and will advise the Department of the results.

Sir:

I have the honor to report that the Chief of the Sucker Creek Indian Band has asked me to write to the Department for a grant of $5.00 from the funds of the Sucker Creek Band to assist in paying for gifts given to the pupils of the school at Christmas.

The Indians usually raised a collection among themselves for this purpose, but on account of so much sickness from Influenza being on the reserve this year he did not feel inclined to collect.

I would recommend that a grant of $5.00 be made for to assist in paying for the presents given to the pupils of the school.

Sir:-

I am in receipt of Official Letter of the 4th instant, in regard to the teacher of the Sucker Creek School reporting for the last fiscal year that the school building should be shingled and the windows repaired, and in reply I have the honour to report that I have examined this building and found the roof in fairly good repair and the teacher informed me that it does not leak.

A few minor repairs might be made to the windows, such as a few cracked glass replaced and a little putty put on in some places, which will not cost very much.

I might say for the information of the Department that it is considered that the attendance at this school in a very short period will be so depleted that it will not warrant a very great expenditure in the way of repairs to the building as the majority of the Indians with families have enfranchised under the provisions of section 122A of the Indian Act and if a few more apply for enfranchisement the school will have to be closed.

Dear Dr. Scott:

I was paying a visit a short time ago to Little Current, and went over to see the Indian Reserve at Sucker Creek.

I was told that His Grace Archbishop Thorneloe had asked the Department of Indian Affairs to build a new school for these Indians, and that it had been understood that a new building would be put up this summer.

The present school building is certainly in a most dilapidated condition, and no teacher can be expected to continue to work there under present conditions.

May I ask that you will be so kind as to look into the matter, so that a commencement may be made as soon as possible, in order that the new school may be ready for use after the holidays.

Believe me,

Yours sincerely,

Sir:

I beg to inform you that a communication has been received from His Lordship the Bishop of Algoma in which he requests that a new day school building be erected on the Sucker Creek Indian Reserve. He states that the present school building is in a most dilapidated condition and that there is urgent need of a new building.

I have to request that you will furnish a full report concerning the condition of the present school building and whether you would recommend that a new building be erected or not. I may say that the present building was erected from Band Funds. The Sucker Creek Band had at their credit in Capital Account as on March 31st, last, $29,640.00. If you consider that a new building is required, you should place the matter before the Band in Council and endeavour to obtain a resolution setting aside from their Funds the amount that would be required to erect a building. You will, no doubt, be able to form an estimate of the size of the building required and the approximate cost of same. You should also state what accommodation is provided at this point for a teacher's living quarters, and the number of children of school age on the Reserve who could attend.

Please let us have the information as requested above at an early date, together with your recommendation as to what you would advise be done in the matter.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Acting Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

Sir:

I am in receipt of Official Letter No. 19-4-5 of the 25th instant, relating to the question of erecting a new school building on the Sucker Creek Reserve, and in reply I have the honour to report to the effect that I cannot recommend that this project be carried out as there are not sufficient Indian pupils on the Sucker Creek Reserve of school age who could attend to warrant such an expenditure. At the present time there are only five pupils of the Sucker Creek Band, three non-treaty, and two pupils whose parents obtained enfranchisement, who could attend.

The building in use as a school at present is not in very good condition but will answer the purpose for the time being.

On my last visit to Sucker Creek I found the members of the band discussing the question of asking the Department to close this school and have the pupils of school age placed in boarding schools but to date not anything further in this matter has developed. If the Indian parents continue to leave the Reserve as they have in the last few years past, the school will be forced to close on account of there not being sufficient pupils.

Your obedient servant,

Indian Agent.

Dear Bishop Smith:

With further reference to your letter of the 13th ultimo, I wish to inform Your Lordship that there are but five children of the Indian Band attending the Sucker Creek School. It is true that there are five others enrolled, but this Department is not responsible for their education. I cannot agree to a new building for such a small activity, especially in view of Mr. Indian Agent Lewis' report that the present equipment, while not in good condition, will answer the purpose for the time being.

If there is no increase in the enrolment of our wards at this school, the Department will seriously consider closing it and having the Indians of school age placed in residential institutions.

Yours very truly,

Duncan C. Scott

Dear Sir,

I would like to draw your attention to the terrible condition of affairs at Sucker Creek School.

The school is built in a regular swamp and during spring and fall is almost unapproachable. Pedestrians must wear long rubber boots to get to the school or sink into the mire.

The school itself is old and dilapidated, only fit for a stable or similar purpose. It is dark, cold and draughty, to say nothing of dirty, and absolutely unfit for the purpose of a school.

At times the water comes up through the floorboards as one walks across the floor. The floor itself has worn down so much that the knots stick up like cobblestone.

One of the Indians, Mr. Thompson, told me the Dept. can have a school-site on his place, right on a hill, dry & clean.

I would like to ask why the present conditions are allowed to continue.
There are 14 pupils on the school list,
8 of whom have full Indian rights.
Most of the others are, of course, illegitimate
and must be counted in as school pupils.

We have written a number of times about
the shocking conditions prevailing yet
nothing is ever done.

Last year an inspector visited the school
to see what was required and was accompanied
by Mr. Papineau and of course nothing was
done. Why must Mr. Papineau be forever
in the foreground? The inspector did
not come near me. Why not? This is
an Anglican School and from the Anglican
clergyman yet Mr. Papineau went
with the inspector while I knew
nothing of the inspectors visit until
he had gone.

We are trying to get our just rights and do
all we can for the uplift of the Indians
under our charge but get no help or
encouragement from the Dept. of Indian
Affairs. Why?

I await your esteemed reply.

Yours sincerely,

Rev. Edwin Weeks
Ottawa, April 10, 1930.

Rev. Sir:

I have your letter of the 5th instant, drawing attention to the present condition of the Sucker Creek Indian Day School, and requesting that a new building be erected on another site. It is noted that the present condition of the school is due, in a certain measure, to the site on which the building is located. I may say in connection with school matters at this point that an Inspector from Headquarters will visit this Reserve during the next few months and enquire into the various matters dealt with in your letter.

Your obedient servant,

This building is very old and in a dilapidated condition. It is past having repairs carried out and unfit for further use as a school building. The condition of this school building would have been reported before now but it was thought that, on account of the unfavourable attendance, it might be the case that the school would close. The attendance from now on will be on the increase and if a school is to be continued a new building will have to be erected to accommodate the pupils as they require a certain degree of comfort which they obtain in the old building in use at present.
Dear Sir,

I wrote you lastly last summer about the terrible state of the school at Sucker Creek Reserve & you promised that the Inspector would be round some time during summer to inspect airport.

I believe he travelled round the island & visited some of the school, but I do not believe he visited Sucker Creek School. If he did, neither the teacher or myself saw anything of him.

The school building is a pitiful disgrace to any civilized country & is only fit for a stable. In bygone days it was used as a Church but finally was condemned to a new Church building erected.

It has served a number of years for a school building but no words can explain its miserable condition.

The Inspector, when he visited this mission before, was accompanied by Mr. Papineau of the Roman Church & he is himself. I understand a Roman Catholic will never get any fair play while in the hands of tubs of those schemers.
I know that Mr. Papineau is trying his old game at Sucker Creek of bringing in children from other reserves; he will no doubt repeat his deception which worked so well at Sheguandah & other places.

Before he applies for a school at Sheguandah I would like to mention that there was, years ago, an agreement between the Dept. of Indian Affairs, the Bishop of the Roman Church & the Bishops of the Anglican Church, in which all agreed that when a reserve was in charge of either Anglican or Roman the other party should not enter.

Mr. Papineau has got himself established in three of our missions contrary to this agreement. He does just whatever he pleases. No one in authority seems to dare to stop him. He can break the law, spurn agreements, deceive & as crooked as he likes, no one can touch him. Whence comes all his power?

I would ask you, sir, if we are to get any justice, any fair play from the Dept. of Indian Affairs or if every branch of the Govt. has sold its soul to the Church of Rome.
Sucker Creek School is hardly fit to burn. It is built in a swamp & almost inaccessible except in the summer months. I enclose a photo of this disreputable building & ask you to please state whether the Dept. of Indian Affairs intends to do anything for us or no.

The photo flatters the building considerably.

I remain Dear Sir,

Yours sincerely

Rev. Edwin Weeks

MEMO FOR FILE:

June 23, 1931.

On the 28th ultimo, I visited the Sucker Creek Indian Day School and found about the most miserable excuse for a school that it has been my fortune to visit. The building is terrible - holes in the floor, etc., and the present teacher, Miss Rosalind Weeks, did not show any enthusiasm. There were four or five children there and one boy had his cap on. Two others were playing marbles in the corner. I was afraid to ask if it was supposed to be recess, because the door was shut and all were in the school. It was a bright, sunny day.

I selected a new site and, as soon as funds are available, the Department will have to rebuild. In the meantime, there is no reason why some effort should not be made with the present equipment, and the first step will be to secure a new teacher.

Mr. Indian Agent Lewis is quite satisfied that the attendance would improve considerably if a good teacher were appointed. The Chief of the Band is supposed to be the truant officer, but he is evidently useless for this purpose. It may be necessary to use the services of the police from time to time.

April 4th, 1932

Dear Mr. [signature],

Acting on your instructions, Mr. Harris asked for a Council Meeting of the Sucker Creek Band.

This was held this evening and I was able to persuade the Council to supply the funds for the building of a new school. However, the resolution was not passed as there was no money on which they demanded a guarantee and to which I was not prepared to promise. They felt that as they are supplying the funds that their labour should be used whenever possible. They have adjourned for one week and have asked me to secure this contract from the Department.

Since then I have seen Mr. Birch, the local contractor whom I have spoken and he says that a scheme could be worked out—using Indians for the excavating and hauling—a cement mixer and his assistant, with two Indian helpers—two carpenters and three or four Indians.
This seems to run to be quite satisfactory and would, I think, meet the demands of the Indians. Would it be possible, however, to give them this promise? The Council meets again on April 11th and I should appreciate an answer before that time.

Mr. Buch tells me that the building should be completed by in a month's time. Is it that we could be possible to commence operations by May 15th so I would like to see the school completed before I leave?

Also, I would like to have a full interview with you and Mr. Buch before things were started. This could be arranged later.

I shall communicate the contents of this letter to Mr. Henry by this post.

Yours truly,

[Signature]

Dear Mr. Dill:

I have your letter of the 4th instant, with reference to the Council Meeting of the Sucker Creek Band, which was held at Mr. Lewis' request. The Council can be assured that the Department will insist on the contractor or foreman using Indians for all rough labour. Of course, the arrangements, whether by contract or day labour, would have to be left with the Department and the Architect. I do not consider it necessary for you to make a special trip to Ottawa in connection with the plans, if the building is proceeded with. We could send you a set and you could make any suggestions you wished.

Pursuant to your Long Distance telephone call, I may say that the Department will insist on controlling the school. All the current expenses would be met from Parliamentary Appropriation, and it would really be in the best interests of the Band itself if we continued our control, as formerly. A copy of this letter is being forwarded to Mr. Lewis, for his information.

Memorandum:

HONOURABLE THOMAS G. MURPHY,

The building at the Sucker Creek Indian Day School has outlived its usefulness and is urgently in need of replacement. As it has not been possible to include items for new buildings in our Estimates, the Department asked the Sucker Creek Band if they were willing to take from the Capital Account of their Band Funds the $6,500 which is needed for a combined classroom and teacher's residence. At the present time, they have sent $2,000 for this account. The Council of the Band approves the willingness to use Band Funds for the purpose, provided that the Department will insist on the employment of Indians for all unskilled labour. I am therefore preparing a memorandum for submission to His Excellency in Council. Section 92 of the Indian Act gives the Governor in Council authority to expend their capital funds in the construction of improvements of permanent value.

If Indians are to be employed as far as possible, the only satisfactory method of construction will be on a day labour basis. It will be necessary to have the name of a competent carpenter foreman of Little Current, to whom we can entrust the work and who will engage whatever skilled labour is necessary. Further, please let me know from what firms in Little Current the Department should purchase the lumber and building hardware.

The Sucker Creek Indian Day School is approximately 4 miles west of Little Current, which is in the federal district of Algoma East.

Acting Deputy Superintendent General.

Sir:

With reference to Departmental Letter No. I9-4-5 of the 29th, of March last with reference to the question of erecting a combined classroom and teacher's residence to replace the old school building at Sucker Creek Reserve, and my letter of the 15th instant enclosing therewith a copy of a motion passed in council by the Indians of Sucker Creek Band authorizing the Department to expend $6,500.00 from their Band Funds for this purpose, I have the honour to report that I am in receipt of a further communication from the Chief of Sucker Creek Band making request that I should ask the Department to let the matter of erecting this building stand over another year. Estimate cost of different jobs contemplated being done to the Sucker Creek School building.

On account of the floor being uneven it is difficult to decide how to repair it. The unevenness of this floor averages 6" from point to point. In order to make a job it will be necessary to lay a complete net work of 2" - 2 x 6 and narrower to cover the floor that is there at the present time, which will necessitate considerable ripping as the 2" will have to be fitted and ripped from a tapering point up to 6". The old platform will have to be torn out. On top of this net work of 2" material a floor of #1 common white pine would answer the purpose. The total cost of leveling and laying floor would be approximately $90.00.

The best way would probably be to tear out the entire floor and under structure, lay new sills where necessary and cover same with 2 x 8's spaced 2' centres. On these joists to put a dressed sheathing floor and over this I x 4 #1 White pine Tongue and groove. By tearing out the entire inside bottom and the price of this complete would cost $195.00.

If the floor is raised instead of being torn out a new door will be required the cost of the door plus hanging etc will amount to $10.00.

To paint to interior walls and ceiling of this building with two coats of good paint any colour the cost of material, labour, scaffold etc will amount to $57.00.

The roof is in poor condition, it may require new sheathing, but cannot tell until the old shingles are taken off. The cost to shingle this building with high class white cedar shingles, which are 8" and up clear, tear off the old shingles, furnish whatever lumber necessary for ridge boards, the total cost for entire job $74.00.

The outside walls of this building are of very old rough lumber which cannot be painted. It would be well to have it whitewashed with lime. The cost of material and labour for one coat would amount to $35.00 or two coats for $65.00.

The total cost of the necessary repairs to this building would amount to at least $296.00.

Dear Sir:

In reply to your letter No. 19-4-5, dated September 13th, I regret that the Indians at Sucker Creek will not consent to provide funds for the repairs of the school from the funds of their band. If I had known this earlier in the year I might have made an appeal for part of the money from the Woman's Auxiliary of this Diocese. It is too late, however, to do that this year, but I will do my best to see what can be done. I am told by our missionary at Little Current that the Chief at Sucker Creek is very hostile to our Church because he wished to have the school building as a meeting house for those strange people who are commonly called "The Holy Rollers". I am, moreover, informed that the activities of these people are producing a very bad effect on the morals of the Indians, men and women rolling about the floor in a most indecent manner. I believe that there is a good deal of truth in these reports.

With regard to the teacher at this school, I have to inform you that Mr. George Dill who, I understand, has been doing work for the Department during the summer at Ottawa, has not returned to his post, and I have appointed Miss Turnbull to take charge of the school for the time being, as an emergency measure. I sincerely hope that the Department will allow Mr. Dill to return to the school as soon as possible as it is extremely difficult, as you know, to find satisfactory teachers so late in the year.
I have not asked for your formal approval of Miss Turnbull because it was an urgent matter, and I understood would only last for a few weeks. I presume that you will pay Mr. Dill for that period and that he will hand on the salary to her.

I do not wish to make any formal complaint, but I think you will agree with me that it is hardly fair that the Department should keep one of our teachers in Ottawa at a time when he should have returned to his post in one of your schools. As I am responsible for the nomination of a teacher to this school, I feel that I should have been consulted in the matter.

Believe me,

Sincerely yours,
